Chapter 26 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Failure to obtain required license. 
    No person shall engage in any profession, trade, occupation or other activity for which a license is required by any federal law, state statute or city ordinance without first obtaining, and thereafter maintaining, such license. 
(Code 2004,  26-1; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(12)) 
Secs. 26-2-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - BUSINESS LICENSES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 6-08, adopted March 4, 2008, amended art. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. 2 consisted of  26-31-26-46, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ordinance No. 3-03, adopted April 1, 2003; and Ordinance No. 4-03, adopted April 1, 2003. 

Sec. 26-31. - Purpose. 
    The city finds that in order to protect the public's health, safety and welfare, and in order to enhance the provision of city services, it is necessary to license businesses, solicitors, and transient merchants operating in the city. Among other matters, the city finds that identifying and registering the nature and scope of businesses, solicitors, and transient merchants assists in the provision of city emergency services and public safety. 
(Code 2004,  26-31; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means any trade, occupation, profession, work, commerce, enterprise, establishment or activity, together with all devices, machines, vehicles, and appurtenances used therein, which is conducted, owned, or operated within the city for private profit or benefit, and any noncommercial organization engaged in actively soliciting funds or donations. The term "business" shall not mean a "home occupation," as that use is defined and regulated pursuant to appendix A, zoning, to this Code. 
    City license officer and license officer mean the city clerk or his designee. 
    Insignia means any tag, plate, badge, emblem, sticker, or any other kind of device which may be required for any use in connection with any license. 
    License and licensee shall include, respectively, the terms "permit" and "permittee" or the holder for any use or period of time of a similar privilege, wherever relevant to any provision of this article or other law or ordinance. 
    Person means individual natural persons, partnerships, joint ventures, societies, associations, clubs, trustees, trusts, or corporations and any kind of personal representative in any capacity, acting either for himself or for any other person, under either personal appointment or pursuant to law. For purposes of this article, the term "person" does not include an individual under the age of 18 years. 
    Premises means all lands, structures, places, and also the equipment and appurtenances connected or used therewith in any business, and also any personal property which is either affixed to or is otherwise used in connection with any such business conducted on such premises. 
    Solicitor or canvasser means any person who travels from place to place, house to house, or street to street by foot or other means of conveyance, and offers for sale, takes orders or attempts to take orders for the commercial sale of any goods, property or service whatsoever for future delivery. "Solicitor" and "canvasser" does not include a person canvassing solely for the limited purpose of distributing religious, political, or other noncommercial information. 
    Transient merchant means any hawker, peddler, or transient vendor as herein defined: 
    Hawker means any person who offers goods, property or services for sale in the streets, highways, thoroughfares or public rights-of-way of the city by crying out, or by signals, music or other noise. 
    Peddler means any person who travels from place to place by foot or any other means of conveyance, for the purpose of displaying, selling, making sales, offering for sale or leasing with the option to buy, at retail, any goods, property or services. "Peddler" also means any person who, while on a public street or while in a public place, offers for sale, takes orders for or attempts to take orders for the retail sale of any goods, personal property or service whatsoever for future delivery. 
    Transient vendor means any person who sells, offers for sale, exhibits, displays, demonstrates or takes orders for the sale of any property or services from any stand, vending cart, or temporary structure. 
(Code 2004,  26-32; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-33. - License required; solicitors and canvassers; transient merchants. 
(a)  Generally. Except as otherwise provided by law, no person shall commence or engage in a business within the city without first obtaining a license pursuant to this article and without keeping such license current during any business operation or activity. 
(b)  Solicitors and canvassers. Except as otherwise provided by law, no person shall engage in business as a solicitor or canvasser within the city, or actively solicit funds or donations of any kind, by any means, without first obtaining a license or permit pursuant to this article and without keeping such license or permit current during any business operation or activity. 
(1)  No solicitor or canvasser, whether licensed pursuant to this article or not, shall barter, sell, or offer for sale any goods, wares, or merchandise, or actively solicit funds on property against the wish or desire of the property owner, tenant, or occupant of such property, as expressed through a "no solicitation" or "no trespassing" sign, a sign displaying words of similar import, or any other means. This section applies to all solicitors, no matter what their purpose, including persons canvassing solely for the limited purpose of distributing religious, political, or other noncommercial information. 
(2)  Any solicitor who engages in business by traveling door to door or house to house may only so operate between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(c)  Transient merchants. Except as otherwise provided by law, no person shall engage in business as a transient merchant within the city without first obtaining a license pursuant to this article and without keeping such license current during any business operation or activity. 
(1)  No transient merchant, whether licensed pursuant to this article or not, shall use the streets, alleys, lanes or public places of the city for the transaction of business or service of customers or operate or maintain any stand, vehicle, store, or place of business on or near to any street, highway or public place in such a manner that the person's customers occupy or congregate within the limits of the street, lane, highway or public place. 
(2)  No transient merchant, whether licensed pursuant to this article or not, shall barter, sell, or offer for sale any goods, wares, or merchandise, or actively solicit funds on property against the wish or desire of the property owner, tenant, or occupant of such property, as expressed through a "no solicitation" or "no trespassing" sign, a sign displaying words of similar import, or any other means. 
(3)  No transient merchant, whether licensed pursuant to this article or not, shall barter, sell, or offer for sale any goods, wares, or merchandise within 500 feet of the entrance to any school building between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on the days when school is in session or on the portion of a street abutting a public park. 
(4)  No person shall engage in business as a transient merchant on or within any street, alley or public place after having been requested to desist by any police officer of the city. 
(5)  Except as permitted by the city, no transient merchant shall, while in any public space, shout or cry out his goods or merchandise, blow any horns, ring any bell, broadcast or play any sound, or use any similar device to attract the attention of the public. 
(6)  A transient merchant may not offer food for sale within 100 feet of any restaurant, storefront, or establishment that sells the same type of food being offered for sale by the transient merchant. 
(d)  Violation of subsections (b) and (c) of this section. Any person that violates any provision of subsection (b) or (c) of this section shall, with respect to each violation, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 2004,  26-33; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-34. - License not transferable. 
    No license may be transferred by the licensee to any other person. Any transfer or attempt to transfer a license will result in the immediate revocation of the license without further action by the city. 
(Code 2004,  26-34; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-35. - License not required for delivery only. 
    A license is not required of any person for the simple delivery in the city of any property purchased or acquired in good faith from such person at his regular place of business outside the city, where no intent is shown to evade the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2004,  26-35; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-36. - Separate license required for branch establishments. 
    A license shall be obtained, in the manner prescribed in this article, for each branch establishment or location of a business, as if each such branch establishment or location were a separate business. 
(Code 2004,  26-36; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-37. - Permits issued to nonprofit enterprises actively soliciting funds or donations. 
    The city license officer shall issue permits, without the payment of any license fees or other charges, to any person or organization for the conduct or operation of a nonprofit enterprise, either regularly or temporarily, when he finds that the applicant operates without private profit for a public, charitable, educational, literary, fraternal, religious or other noncommercial purpose. Persons or organizations conducting or operating nonprofit enterprises are required to apply for and obtain a permit under this article only if such persons or organizations are actively soliciting funds or donations of any kind, by whatever means, as opposed to canvassing solely for the limited purpose of distributing religious, political or other noncommercial information. An applicant for a permit shall submit an application to the city license officer and, when operating under a permit, shall operate his enterprise in compliance with this article and all other applicable rules and regulations. 
(Code 2004,  26-37; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-38. - Duties of city license officer. 
    The city license officer shall collect all license fees, if any, shall issue licenses in the name of the city to all persons qualified under the provisions of this article, and shall also: 
(1)  Rules. Promulgate and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations necessary in the operation and enforcement of this article. 
(2)  Affidavits. Require applicants to submit all affidavits and oaths necessary to the administration of this article. 
(3)  Departmental review. Submit all applications, in a proper case, to appropriate city departments for review as to compliance by the applicant with all city laws which they have the duty of enforcing. 
(4)  Investigation. Investigate and determine the eligibility of any applicant for a license as prescribed in this article including, without limitation, requiring the applicant to establish authority to operate on private property. 
(5)  Examination. Examine such records of an applicant as deemed reasonably necessary to the administration and enforcement of this article. 
(6)  Notification. Notify an applicant of the acceptance or rejection of his application and, upon the refusal of a license or permit, at the applicant's request, state in writing the reasons therefore and deliver them to the applicant. 
(Code 2004,  26-38; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-39. - Qualifications of applicants for licenses. 
(a)  In general. The general standards set out in this section relative to the qualifications of every applicant for a city license shall be considered and applied by the city license officer: 
(b)  Compliance with zoning regulations. The applicant must comply with all zoning restrictions of the city as determined by city officials or employees; provided, however, that this requirement shall not apply for purposes of this article only to a business in lawful operation as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived or to a business applying for renewal of a valid license. 
(1)  The applicant's business shall not be illegal or violate any federal, state, county, or city statute, law, rule, regulation, or ordinance. 
(2)  If required by law, the applicant shall furnish with the application proof of a valid health permit issued by the county health department. 
(3)  The applicant must submit to a background investigation where requested by the city. As permitted by state law, the city may require fingerprinting for such background investigations. The city may charge the applicant the appropriate fee for the background investigations. 
(Code 2004,  26-39; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-40. - Procedure for issuance of license. 
(a)  Formal application required. Every person required to procure a license under the provisions of any ordinance or law of the city shall submit an application for such license to the city license officer. The application shall be: 
(1)  Submitted in writing upon forms approved by the city and provided by the city license officer. Such form shall include a sworn affidavit by the applicant and shall require the disclosure of all information necessary for compliance with this article and of any other information which the city license officer shall find to be reasonably necessary for the fair administration of this article. 
(2)  Accompanied by a payment in full of the application fee established by resolution of the city commission from time to time. 
(b)  Initial license. In order to obtain a license as required by this article, an applicant shall submit an application not less than 30 days prior to the time the applicant wishes to begin conducting business. 
(c)  Issuance of receipts. Whenever a license cannot be issued at the time the application for the license is made, the city license officer shall issue a receipt to the applicant for the money paid in advance. Such receipt shall not be construed as the approval by the city license officer for the issuance of a license, nor shall it entitle or authorize the applicant to open or maintain any business contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Renewal license procedure. An applicant for the renewal of a license shall submit an application for such license to the city license officer in accordance with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. An application for renewal of a license shall be submitted not later than June 15 of each year. If an applicant fails to file its application for renewal on or before June 15, the city license officer shall not be required to approve or disapprove the license before the expiration of the current license. 
(e)  Nonapproval of license. The license officer shall, upon disapproving any application submitted under the provisions of this article, advise the applicant, in writing, of the denial and the basis for the same including, without limitation, the results of any background check. 
(f)  Compliance with article pending legal action. When the issuance of a license is denied and an action is instituted by the applicant to compel its issuance, such applicant shall not engage in the business for which the license was refused unless and until a license be issued pursuant to a judgment ordering the same. 
(g)  Right of appeal. Any person aggrieved by the action of the license officer in the denial of an application for a license as provided in this article, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a license as provided in section 26-45(c), shall have the right of appeal to the city ordinance committee. Such appeal shall be made by filing with the city license officer, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The city ordinance committee shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided in section 26-45(c). The decision and order of the city ordinance committee on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(h)  Conditions of approval. Any license issued by the city shall, as a condition to its issuance, be subject to all terms and conditions contained in this article. 
(Code 2004,  26-40; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-41. - Fees. 
    Fees for applications for a business license pursuant to this article shall be established by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 2004,  26-41; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-42. - Duties of licensee. 
(a)  General standards of conduct. Every licensee under this article must comply with the following general standards of conduct. Failure to comply with such standards shall result in revocation of a license. 
(1)  Permit and cooperate with the reasonable inspection of the business by public authorities so authorized by law. 
(2)  Ascertain and at all times comply with all laws, codes, regulations, and ordinances applicable to such licensed business, including obtaining and maintaining any other licenses required by city ordinance, state law, or federal law. 
(3)  Avoid all forbidden, improper, or unnecessary practices or conditions which do or may affect the public health, safety, or welfare. 
(4)  Refrain from operating the licensed businesses on premises after expiration of a license or during the period a license is revoked or suspended. 
(5)  Refrain from transferring or assigning a license to any other person. 
(6)  Comply with all other provisions of this article. 
(b)  Display of license and insignia. Every licensee under this article shall: 
(1)  Carry any license issued in accordance with the provisions of this article upon his person at all times when engaged in the activity for which the license was granted. Where such licensed activity for which the license was issued occurs in a fixed place or establishment, the license shall be exhibited at all times in a conspicuous place so that it may be readily seen by persons entering the premises. Every licensee shall produce the license for examination when applying for a renewal thereof or when requested to do so by any city police officer or by any other city official or employee. 
(2)  Not allow any license, special permit, or insignia to remain posted, displayed, or used after the period for which it was issued has expired, or when it has been suspended or revoked, or for any other reason has become ineffective. The licensee shall promptly return such inoperative license, permit, or insignia to the license officer. 
(3)  Not loan, sell, give, or assign, to any other person, or allow any other person to use or display, or to destroy, damage, or remove, or to have in his possession, except as authorized by the license officer or by law, any license or insignia which has been issued to such licensee. 
(Code 2004,  26-42; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-43. - Agents responsible for compliance. 
    The agents or other representatives of licensees who are doing business in this city shall be personally responsible for the compliance with this article by their principals and by the businesses they represent. 
(Code 2004,  26-43; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-44. - Term, expiration date of licenses. 
    All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall be annual licenses and shall be valid from date of issuance to the following June 30 (unless earlier revoked). Licenses issued pursuant to other city ordinances shall expire as provided by such ordinances. 
(Code 2004,  26-44; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-45. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Inspections. The following persons are authorized to conduct inspections in the manner prescribed in this section: 
(1)  City license officer. The city license officer shall make all investigations reasonably necessary for enforcement of this article. 
(2)  Officials having duties. The city license officer shall have the authority to request the inspection of licensees, their businesses and premises, by all city officials or employees having duties to perform with reference to such licensees or businesses. 
(3)  Police officers. All police officers may inspect and examine businesses licensed pursuant to this article to enforce compliance with this article. 
(4)  Code officials. All code officials, including, but not limited to, members of the fire department, may inspect and examine businesses licensed pursuant to this article to enforce compliance with city codes or this article. 
(b)  Authority of inspectors. A condition of any license or permit is that all persons authorized to inspect licensees and businesses pursuant to this article may enter, with or without search warrant, during business hours and at other reasonable times, the following premises: 
(1)  Those for which a license has been applied but not finally issued. 
(2)  Those for which a license was issued and which, at the time of inspection, are operating under a license. 
(3)  Those for which a license is required in accordance with this article. 
(c)  Revocation of license. When a person fails to comply with the standards of conduct or any other requirement of this article, engages in actions contrary to the health, safety, or welfare of the public, engages in unauthorized business or business that is beyond the scope of the license granted, or in violation of any other law or ordinance, the license officer shall issue an order to comply; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall limit the rights of the city to otherwise enforce its ordinances to the extent permitted by law. Such order, and all other notices issued in compliance with this article, shall be in writing and shall apprise the person affected of the nature of the violations. A copy of such order shall be affixed to some structure on the premises and shall be deposited in the United States mail to the last known address of the person affected, which action shall constitute proper service. 
(1)  Period for compliance. The order shall require compliance within a reasonable time identified in the order following service on the affected person. 
(2)  Hearing. Upon written appeal by the person affected, received before the expiration of the period for compliance, the city license officer shall order a hearing consistent with section 26-40(g). Notice of such a hearing shall be given to the affected person in the manner prescribed for the original order of compliance. 
(3)  Modifying authority of license officer. Upon written request on his own motion, the license officer shall have the authority, for good cause shown, to extend the time for compliance, to grant a new hearing date, and to change, modify or rescind any recommendation or order. 
(4)  Final order. Upon the failure or refusal of a violator to comply with the provisional order or with order made after hearing, the license officer shall declare and make the order of compliance final. 
a.  Authority of license officer. The license officer shall have the authority to suspend or revoke a license issued pursuant to this article upon making or declaring an order of compliance final. 
b.  Effect of revocation or suspension. Upon revocation or suspension of a license, no refund of any portion of the license fee shall be made to the licensee and he shall immediately cease all business at all places for which the license was issued. 
(5)  Summary action. When the conduct of any licensee, agent, or employee is so inimical to the public health, safety, and general welfare as to constitute a nuisance and give rise to an emergency, the license officer shall have the authority to summarily order the cessation of business and the close of premises or to suspend or revoke the license. Unless waived in writing, within seven days after he has acted summarily, the license officer shall conduct a hearing for such action in respect to the summary order as may be therein determined. Notice of such hearing shall be given the affected person by personal service and in the manner as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(6)  Right to appeal. Any person aggrieved by any decision of the license officer after hearing shall have the right to appeal to the city commission committee of the whole by filing a written appeal as provided in section 26-40(g) within ten business days after receipt of notice of such decision. 
(Code 2004,  26-45; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008; Memo of 8-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-46. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Violation. Unless otherwise specified in this article, a person who violates a provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Other relief. In addition to the remedies and penalties otherwise provided in this article, the city may seek temporary and permanent equitable relief to abate and enjoin violations of this article and shall have all other remedies provided by law or equity. 
(Code 2004,  26-46; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-47. - Exempt persons. 
    The following persons shall be exempt from the licensing requirements of this article, but shall be subject to the other provisions hereof: 
(a)  Noncommercial. Any person offering to sell goods or products on behalf of, churches or other organizations involving religious worship or observance, public or private schools, youth organizations, or other noncommercial entities; provided, however, that any such church, school, youth organization, or noncommercial entity shall be recognized as a tax-exempt charitable, educational, or religious organization under the United States Internal Revenue Code or as defined under Michigan General Property Tax Act, being Public Act 206 of 1893, as amended. 
(b)  Salespersons. Any permanently employed and bonded route salespersons that solicit orders from and distribute goods to regular customers on established routes. 
(c)  Otherwise exempt. Any person exempt from the licensing requirements of this article by virtue of state or federal law. 
(Code 2004,  26-47; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-48. - Special events license. 
    A nonprofit, religious, cultural, charitable or educational organization sponsoring a special event with a duration not to exceed two days may obtain a special event license which shall excuse such vendors conducting business at the special event from obtaining a license as otherwise required by this article. A special event license shall be issued only under the following conditions: 
(a)  Organization sponsor. The special event license shall apply only to those transient merchants conducting business at the special event under the auspices of, and with the permission of, the organization obtaining the special event license. 
(b)  Maintenance of record. The organization sponsoring the special event shall maintain a record containing the name, address, e-mail address, telephone number and date of birth of each transient merchant operating under its auspices at the special event. This record shall be displayed to any law enforcement officer or any representative of the city upon request. 
(c)  Single location. A special event license shall be issued only for a single location. 
(d)  Other laws. The organization sponsoring the special event and all transient merchants conducting business at the special event shall comply with all other applicable provisions of this Code and all provisions of any other applicable ordinance, law, rule or regulation. 
(e)  Written application. Applicants for a special event license must file a written application with the city clerk on a form furnished by the city clerk. 
(f)  Revocation. A special event license shall not be transferable and may be revoked at any time for failure to comply with the provisions of this Code or any of the conditions set forth in the license. 
(Code 2004,  26-48; Ord. No. 6-08,  1, 3-28-2008) 
Sec. 26-49. - Commercial snow plowers license. 
(a)  Commercial snow plowers are required to obtain a snow plow license for each vehicle used to move snow within the city except: dump trucks and front end loaders. 
(b)  All owners of such vehicles must provide a copy of current vehicle registration and proof of insurance of contractor's motor vehicle bodily injury and property damage insurance in the amount of $100,000.00 per person, $300,000.00 per accident, bodily injury, including accidental death: $100,000.00 per occurrence, property damage with fees for each vehicle pursuant to this article set by city commission resolution from time to time. 
Secs. 26-50-26-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - ADULT-ORIENTED ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 26-331. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult cabaret means a nightclub, restaurant or other establishment which regularly features or displays: 
(1)  Live performances predominantly characterized by an emphasis on the exposure of any specified anatomical area or by any specified sexual activity; or 
(2)  Films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, other photographic reproductions or visual media predominantly characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of any specified sexual activity or specified anatomical area. 
    Adult merchandise store means an establishment having as a substantial or significant portion of its stock in trade merchandise which is predominantly distinguished or characterized by its emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to any specified sexual activity or specified anatomical area. 
    Adult motel means a hotel, motel or similar establishment that offers: 
(1)  Accommodation to the public for any form of consideration and provides patrons with closed-circuit television (as distinguished from commercial cable services) transmissions, films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, other photographic reproductions or visual media that are characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of any specified sexual activity or specified anatomical area; or 
(2)  A sleeping room for rent, or allows a tenant or occupant of a sleeping room to subrent the room, for a period of time that is less than ten hours, if the rental of such room accounts for more than ten percent of the establishment's gross revenues. 
    Adult-oriented business means a business or commercial establishment engaging in one or more of the following enterprises: 
(1)  Adult cabaret; 
(2)  Adult merchandise store; 
(3)  Adult motel; 
(4)  Adult theater; 
(5)  Escort agency; 
(6)  Nude model studio; or 
(7)  Sexual encounter center. 
    Adult theater means a theater, concert hall, auditorium or similar establishment which regularly features live performances predominantly characterized by an emphasis on the exposure of any specified anatomical area or by any specified sexual activity or which regularly or primarily shows films, motion pictures, videocassettes, slides, other photographic reproductions or visual media predominantly characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of any specified sexual activity or specified anatomical area. This definition includes, without limitation, establishments which offer individual viewing booths. 
    Escort means a person who, for any form of consideration and regardless of who pays the consideration, agrees or offers to act as a companion or date for another person, or who agrees or offers to privately model lingerie or to privately perform a striptease for another person. 
    Escort agency means a person or entity which furnishes, offers to furnish or advertises to furnish escorts as one of its primary business purposes for a fee, tip or other consideration. An escort agency is deemed to be operated in the location where: 
(1)  A request for an escort is received; or 
(2)  The escort and the person requesting the escort are together. 
    Material means anything tangible, whether through the medium of reading, observation, sound or in any other manner, including, but not limited to, anything printed or written, any book, magazine, newspaper, pamphlet, picture, drawing, pictorial representation, motion picture, photograph, videotape, videodisk, film, transparency, slide, audiotape, audiodisk, computer tape, holographic image or any other medium used to electronically produce or reproduce images, or any mechanical, chemical or electronic reproduction. Such term includes undeveloped photographs, molds, printing plates and other latent representational objects, whether or not processing or other acts are required to make the content of the material apparent. This definition is intended to include material which is the product of any technology, whether that technology is available on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived or becomes available after that date. 
    Merchandise means material and novelties. 
    Novelty means any instrument, device or paraphernalia which depicts or describes any specific anatomical area or any specific sexual act, or which is designed for use, or commonly used, in connection with specific sexual activities, excluding condoms and other birth control and disease prevention products. 
    Nude model studio means any place where a person displays any specified anatomical area as provided to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured, photographed or similarly depicted by any other person who pays money or any form of consideration. 
    Sexual encounter center means an establishment, except that which is part of the practice, and under the supervision and control, of a physician, psychologist or psychiatrist, licensed to practice in the state, that offers: 
(1)  Activities between male and female persons and/or persons of the same sex when one or more of the persons exposes or displays any specified anatomical area; or 
(2)  The matching and/or exchanging of persons for any specified sexual activities. 
    Specified anatomical area means any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, anus or female breast at or below the top of the areola; or 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activity means any of the following: 
(1)  The fondling or other erotic touching of the human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus or female breast; 
(2)  A sex act, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation or sodomy; 
(3)  Masturbation, actual or simulated; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of, or in connection with, any of the activities set forth in subsections (1), (2) or (3) of this definition. 
(Code 2004,  26-331; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.871) 
Sec. 26-332. - Permitting or aiding or abetting violations. 
    The following shall be a misdemeanor: 
(1)  Permitting, allowing, encouraging or promoting any violation of any provision of this article, including any owner, manager, employee, patron, customer, officer, partner or other person; or 
(2)  Aiding, assisting or abetting the violation of any provision of this article. 
(Code 2004,  26-332; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.876) 
Sec. 26-333. - General requirements for adult-oriented businesses. 
    All adult-oriented businesses shall comply with the following: 
(1)  No person under the age of 18 years shall enter or be on the premises of an adult-oriented business at any time the adult-oriented business is open, nor shall any owner, partner, performer, contractor or employee of an adult-oriented business sell or provide goods, merchandise or services to persons under the age of 18 years. 
(2)  The following shall not be visible or audible to a person outside the building in which an adult-oriented business is operated, whether through a window or doorway, or otherwise: 
a.  Any depiction or description in any material of any specified sexual activity or specified anatomical area; 
b.  Any novelty; or 
c.  Any person engaging in any specified sexual activity or exposing any specified anatomical area. 
(3)  No adult-oriented business shall allow the consumption of alcohol on the premises of the business. 
(4)  No person or establishment shall operate an adult-oriented business: 
a.  Before 8:00 a.m. or after midnight, on Monday through Saturday; or 
b.  On any Sunday or legal holiday. 
(5)  No adult-oriented business shall engage in business unless each of the following are satisfied: 
a.  At least two employees, excluding entertainers, are on the premises of the business at all times the business is open; and 
b.  The business is equipped with operational security cameras which shall be used at all times the business is open. 
(6)  Any booth, room or cubicle located in any adult-oriented business, except an adult motel, used by patrons for the viewing of merchandise or any other entertainment must comply with all of the following requirements: 
a.  It must be unobstructed by any door, lock or other entrance and exit control device; 
b.  One side must be totally open to a public, lighted aisle so that there is an unobstructed view at all times from the adjoining aisle of any occupant; 
c.  It must be illuminated so that a person of normal visual acuity looking into the booth, room or cubicle from the entrance adjoining the public lighted aisle can clearly determine the number of people within; and 
d.  There shall be no holes or openings in any side or rear wall not relating to utility, ventilation or temperature control services or otherwise required by any governmental code or authority. 
(7)  No sign or advertising for an adult-oriented business may include any photographs, silhouettes, drawings or other representations of any specified anatomical area or specified sexual activity. 
(8)  All adult-oriented businesses shall be open to inspection by the city's ordinance enforcement officer, building inspector, fire inspector, police officer, sheriff's deputy and state police trooper for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the law at any time the establishment is occupied or open for business. 
(Code 2004,  26-333; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.872) 
Sec. 26-334. - Additional requirements for adult-oriented businesses offering live entertainment. 
(a)  Any adult-oriented business offering live entertainment shall provide all of the following: 
(1)  A dressing room for performers, with direct access between the dressing area and the performance area or stage so that the performer may enter the performance area or stage without entering the area from which patrons will view the performance; 
(2)  The access, performance area or stage and dressing room shall be handicapped accessible to the extent required by the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Elliott-Larsen Civil Rights Act (MCL 37.2101 et seq.); 
(3)  All performances shall occur on a stage elevated at least 18 inches above the immediate floor level and removed at least six feet from the nearest employee or patron; and 
(4)  The dressing area for performers shall be separate and not freely accessible from areas of the business accessible to patrons, and the dressing area shall contain hot and cold running water and toilet facilities. 
(b)  There shall be no physical contact between any performer and any other performer or between any performer and any owner, independent contractor, employee, patron or other person during or for at least 15 minutes following such performance. The term "physical contact" includes, but is not limited to, any contact in which any part of the body or clothing of one person touches any part of the body or clothing of the other person, or if a person causes anything under that person's direct control to touch any part of the body or clothing of another person. 
(c)  Each escort agency shall maintain permanent records on the premises, showing the name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of every person for whom an escort is provided, the fee paid, the name of the escort provided, and the location where the escort and the person requesting the escort initially meet. The records shall be made available, upon demand, to any city official inspecting the premises pursuant to this article. 
(Code 2004,  26-334; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.873) 
Sec. 26-335. - Registration. 
    Each adult-oriented business shall register its existence with the city clerk and zoning administrator prior to commencing business, or, in the case of a business lawfully operating prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, within 30 days after such effective date. The registration shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The name, residence address, e-mail address, business address and telephone number of the applicant and manager. If the applicant is a partnership, limited liability company, corporation or similar business entity, the name, residence address and e-mail address of each of the officers, directors, managers and each of the owners, partners or shareholders owning ten percent interest or more, either directly or beneficially, shall also be provided. 
(2)  The name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of the owner of the building where the business will be conducted, and of the building manager, if different from the owner. 
(3)  The location, mailing address and all telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted. 
(Code 2004,  26-335; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.874) 
Sec. 26-336. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  Except on a stage or other area of performance as specified in section 26-334, no person within an adult-oriented business shall display any specified anatomical area to the view of any other person. 
(b)  No person shall engage in any specified sexual activity on the premises of an adult-oriented business. 
(Code 2004,  26-336; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.875) 
Secs. 26-337-26-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 4. - MASSAGE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Massage therapy, MCL 333.17951 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adamitism means the practice of going naked, and the state of being unclothed. 
    Anilingus means erotic stimulation achieved by contact between the mouth or tongue and the anus. 
    Coprophilia means the use of feces for sexual excitement. 
    Cunnilingus means the stimulation of the vulva or clitoris with the lips or tongue. 
    Fellation means the practice of obtaining sexual gratification by oral stimulation of the penis. 
    Flagellation means an act or instance of obtaining sexual gratification by beating, flogging or scourging another or being the recipient of such action. 
    Frottage means masturbation by rubbing against another person. 
    Manager means each person who is responsible for the daily operation of a massage establishment. 
    Massage and practice of massage means the application of a system of structured touch, pressure, movement, and holding to the soft tissue of the human body in which the primary intent is to enhance or restore the health and well-being of the client. Practice of massage includes complementary methods, including the external application of water, heat, cold, lubrication, salt scrubs, body wraps, or other topical preparations; and electromechanical devices that mimic or enhance the actions possible by the hands. Practice of massage does not include medical diagnosis; practice of physical therapy; high-velocity, low-amplitude thrust to a joint; electrical stimulation; application of ultrasound; or prescription of medicines. 
    Massage establishment means a building, room, place or establishment where body massage is regularly practiced on the human body to club members or to the general public for a charge, but such term shall not include hospitals, nursing homes, medical clinics or offices of state licensed physicians, surgeons, osteopaths or chiropractors. 
    Masturbation means the erotic practice involving the genital organs commonly resulting in orgasm and achieved by manual or other bodily contact, exclusive of sexual intercourse, or by instrumental manipulation. 
    Massage therapist means a person who is compensated for the practice of massage but shall not include the professionals identified in section 26-372(1) through (4) when practicing their respective professions. 
    Sexual intercourse means carnal copulation of a male and female implying actual intercourse of the organs of the female. 
    Sodomy means penetration of the male organ into the anus of another person. 
    Urolagnia means sexual excitement associated with the urine or urination. 
(Code 2004,  26-371; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.761; Ord. No. 9-14,  1, 12-16-2014) 
Sec. 26-372. - Exclusions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following persons while engaged in the personal performance of the duties of their respective professions: 
(1)  Any medical doctor, doctor of osteopathic medicine, doctor of chiropractic medicine, physical therapist, psychiatrist, psychologist, clinical social worker or family counselor who is licensed to practice his respective profession in the state, or who is permitted to practice temporarily under the auspices of an association or establishment duly licensed in the state. 
(2)  Nurses who are registered under the laws of the state and who administer a massage in the normal course of their nursing duties. 
(3)  A barber, manicurist, beautician or cosmetologist who is duly licensed under the laws of this state or another state within the United States, or the federal government, and who practices within the established limits of his license, and who administers a massage in the normal course of his duties; provided, however, that such barber, manicurist, beautician or cosmetologist shall perform a massage only upon the face, hands, feet or neck of another person, and performs the practice of massage for beautifying or cosmetic purposes only. 
(4)  Any athletic trainer who has been certified by the National Athletic Trainers Association or who is employed by one of the public schools or state approved nonpublic schools, as such terms are used in state law, and who is performing massage on the school premises. 
(5)  Massage therapists who meet the current requirements of the state in accordance with part 179A of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.17951 et seq.). 
(6)  Any establishment in which only the persons described in subsections (1)-(4) of this section exclusively practice their respective professions. 
(Code 2004,  26-372; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.752(D); Ord. No. 9-14,  2, 12-16-2014) 
Sec. 26-373. - Inspections. 
(a)  The premises of each massage establishment shall be open to inspection by the city at all reasonable times. 
(b)  A licensee shall not hinder, obstruct, resist or oppose such inspection by the city. 
(Code 2004,  26-373; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.767) 
Sec. 26-374. - Physical establishment standards. 
    Each massage establishment shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  All tables, tubs, shower stalls and floors, except reception and administrative areas, shall be made of nonporous materials which may be readily disinfected. 
(2)  Closed cabinets shall be provided and used for the storage of clean linens, towels and other materials used in connection with administering massages. 
(3)  Closed containers shall be provided for soiled linens, towels and waste materials. 
(4)  Separate toilets, lavatory facilities and shower stalls shall be supplied for patrons and personnel of the establishment. Separate toilet facilities and shower stalls shall be provided for male and female patrons. Each area in which massage is practiced shall be equipped with a hand lavatory. No toilet, lavatory facility or shower stall may be used in conjunction with any other business and such toilets, lavatories and shower stalls shall be located so as to ensure privacy between the massage establishment and any other business or use. 
(5)  All equipment, shower stalls, toilets, lavatories and any other such accoutrements shall be regularly treated by disinfectants and shall be maintained at all times in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(6)  No part of the premises shall be used for, or connected with, any bedroom or sleeping quarters; nor shall any person sleep in a massage establishment, except for a limited period incidental, and directly related, to a massage or bath. No bed, water mattress, cot or equipment designed for sleeping shall be permitted on the premises. 
(7)  There shall be no locks on any interior door to any room in which any person engages in the practice of massage. 
(8)  No massage shall be performed in a massage establishment in a private room which is completely closed to the view of other persons. Each room in which any person will engage in the practice of massage shall have an unobstructed opening or window of a size not less than six inches by ten inches and which is located no less than four or more than six feet above the floor, from which the massage area of the room in which the massage is to be administered is clearly visible. 
(9)  All exterior doors and the door separating the waiting/reception area from the remainder of the premises shall remain unlocked during business hours. 
(10)  No massage establishment or any part of the premises shall be equipped with any electronic, mechanical or artificial device used, or capable of being used, for recording, videotaping or monitoring the activities, conversation or other sounds in a room used by customers. 
(Code 2004,  26-374; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.765) 
Sec. 26-375. - Sanitation standards. 
    Each massage establishment shall comply with the following standards: 
(1)  A massage shall not be performed on any patron who is infected with any fungus or other skin infection; nor shall any service be performed on a patron exhibiting skin inflammation or eruptions, or having any contagious or communicable disease unless a duly licensed physician has certified that such person may be safely served. 
(2)  All personnel shall wash their hands in hot water with soap before giving any service or treatment to each separate patron. 
(3)  All towels, tissues, sheets or other coverings shall be used singularly for each patron and discarded for laundry or disposal immediately after use. 
(4)  Nondisposable tools of the trade shall be disinfected after each use upon a patron. 
(5)  All employees shall at all times wear clean outer garments, the use of which is restricted to the massage establishment. The garments shall be opaque and shall cover the torso, legs, and sexual and genital parts of the employee's body. 
(6)  Employees shall not attend to a patron if the employee has any contagious or communicable disease. 
(7)  The sexual and genital areas of patrons and customers must be covered by towels, cloths or opaque garments at all times when in the presence of any massage therapist or employee of a massage establishment. 
(Code 2004,  26-375; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.766) 
Sec. 26-376. - Regulated and unlawful activities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any massage establishment to offer, or massage therapist or any other employee to offer or engage in, adamitism, anilingus, cunnilingus, coprophilia, fellation, flagellation, frottage, masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolagnia or any intentional stimulation of the sexual or genital parts of the human body. 
(b)  No alcoholic liquor, or controlled substance, as such term is defined by state law, shall be sold or otherwise provided to patrons or customers on the premises of any massage establishment, except for the sale of alcoholic liquors at massage establishments which have obtained a valid license pursuant to the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998 (MCL 436.1101 et seq.). 
(c)  A massage therapist shall not practice massage upon a person who is visibly intoxicated by, or under the influence of, any liquor or controlled substance. 
(d)  A massage therapist shall not practice massage while intoxicated or under the influence of any liquor or controlled substance. 
(e)  A massage therapist shall not practice massage upon any person under the age of 18 years, except upon written order by a licensed medical doctor, doctor of osteopathic medicine or physical therapist, and such order shall be dated and in the possession of the massage therapist giving the massage or treatment. If the person under the age of 18 years is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian during the massage or treatment, this subsection shall not apply. Otherwise, no person under the age of 18 years shall enter or remain, nor shall any owner or operator allow such person to enter or remain, on the premises of a massage establishment at any time. 
(f)  Every massage establishment shall maintain permanent records on the premises showing the name, address, e-mail address, telephone number and signature of every person receiving massage services, the date and time of the massage, the type of massage services provided, the fee paid for such services, the name of the person providing the massage services, and must also indicate that such information was verified through the display of positive identification (i.e., indicate a driver's license was displayed to verify information provided). The record shall be made available, upon demand and without prior notice, to any city official inspecting the premises pursuant to section 26-373. 
(Code 2004,  26-376; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.768) 
Secs. 26-377-26-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 26-401. - Required. 
(a)  No person shall operate a massage establishment without first securing a license to do so from the city. 
(b)  No person shall employ as a massage therapist any person who does not meet the current requirements of the state in accordance with part 179A of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.17951 et seq.), as required by this division. 
(c)  No person shall engage in, advertise, solicit or offer to engage in the practice of massage or massage therapy for compensation without meeting the current requirements of the State of Michigan in accordance with part 179A of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.17951 et seq.). 
(Code 2004,  26-401; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.762(A)-(C); Ord. No. 9-14,  3, 12-16-2014) 
Sec. 26-402. - Massage establishments. 
(a)  An application to operate a massage establishment shall be made to the city clerk. The application shall be made under oath, stating that the information contained in the application is true and accurate and upon a form provided by the city clerk. Any false statement set forth in an application shall be a violation of this article and be cause for revocation of the license. The nonrefundable license fee must be paid and the license shall not be processed until the following information has been supplied: 
(1)  The names, residence addresses, e-mail addresses, business addresses and telephone numbers of each applicant and manager. If the applicant is a corporation, the names, residence addresses and e-mail addresses of each of the officers and directors of the corporation and each shareholder owning ten percent interest or more in the corporation, either directly or beneficially, shall also be given. If the applicant is a partnership, the names, residence addresses and e-mail addresses of each general partner shall also be given. 
(2)  The name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of the owner of the building where the business will be conducted, and the name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of the building manager, if different from the owner. 
(3)  The two previous addresses and telephone numbers immediately prior to the present address of the applicant and all managers. 
(4)  The location, mailing address and all telephone numbers where the business is to be conducted. 
(5)  Written proof that the applicant, if an individual or partnership, and all managers are at least 18 years of age. 
(6)  A copy of identification from each manager and applicant, such as a driver's license, if an individual; partnership agreement and certificate, if a partnership; or certificate of good standing from the state, if a corporation. 
(7)  Two identical photographs and a set of fingerprints of each individual applicant, each manager, each general partner of a partnership applicant, and each officer and managing agent of a corporate applicant. All photographs and fingerprints shall be taken by the city police department or another governmental agency acceptable to the city police department. 
(8)  Business, occupation or employment of each applicant and manager for three years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(9)  The business history of the applicant for the five years prior to the date of the application, including all individuals identified in subsection (a)(1) of this section, whether such applicant, including all individuals identified in subsection (a)(1) of this section, in previously operating in this or another city or state has had a business license denied, revoked or suspended, the reason for the denial, revocation or suspension, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to the denial, revocation or suspension. 
(10)  All criminal pleas or convictions of the individuals identified in subsection (a)(1) of this section, including the dates of each plea or conviction, nature of the crime and place convicted. 
(11)  The name and address of any other massage business owned or operated by any person identified in subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(12)  A description of any other business to be operated on the same premises or on adjoining premises owned or controlled by the applicant. 
(13)  The name, address and e-mail address of each massage therapist and other employees who are or will be employed in the massage establishment. 
(14)  Authorization for the city, its agents and employees to seek information and conduct an investigation into the truth of the statements set forth in the application and the qualifications of the applicant for the license. 
(15)  Such other identification and information necessary to verify the truth of the matters required to be set forth in the application. 
(16)  A certification by the city's building inspector that the physical standards for the establishment as set forth in section 26-374 and any other relevant standards of this article have been met. Prior to issuing such certification, the building inspector shall obtain prior approval of all appropriate city departments, including, but not limited to, the fire department and police department. 
(17)  The annual license fee for each massage establishment, which shall be established from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(18)  The names, current addresses, e-mail addresses, telephone numbers and written statements of at least three permanent residents of the United States that the applicant, including all individuals identified in subsection (a)(1) of this section, is of good moral character. The term "good moral character" means the propensity on the part of an individual to serve the public in a fair, open and honest manner. If the applicant is able, the statement must first be furnished from residents of the city, then the county, then the state and lastly from the rest of the United States. The references must be persons other than relatives. 
(b)  The applicant or holder of a license shall notify the city clerk in writing of each change in any of the data required to be furnished by this section within ten days after such change occurs. 
(c)  The license granted under this section shall be for one year, beginning July 1 of each year. A license granted under this section is nontransferable. 
(d)  Each employee of an establishment licensed under this section shall be issued an identification card containing such information as the city shall specify thereon. Such card shall be carried by such employee at all times while such employee is on the licensed premises. 
(e)  Upon the sale or transfer of any interest in a massage establishment, the license shall be void. A new application shall be made by any person desiring to own or operate the massage establishment. 
(f)  The owner and operator of a massage establishment shall display the license in a conspicuous place at all times so that it may be readily seen by persons entering the premises. 
(g)  The owner and operator of a licensed massage establishment shall maintain a copy of this article on the premises for public inspection at all times during business hours. 
(Code 2004,  26-402; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.763) 
Sec. 26-403. - Repealed. 
Sec. 26-404. - Denial or revocation. 
(a)  Any application for a license under this division may be denied by the city clerk if there are any false statements set forth in the application and any license granted in this division may be revoked by the city commission for violation of any other provision of this article or any other city ordinance or state statute, or upon a determination that the continued operation under an existing license shall be contrary to the public health, safety or welfare. Appeal of the denial of a license by the city clerk shall be made to the city commission. Except as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, before the city commission revokes a license issued in this division or upon appeal from the denial of a license by the city clerk, the city commission shall cause a written notice to be sent by certified mail to the licensee or applicant affected, at the address stated in the license or application, informing such person of the right to a hearing, upon request. If the licensee does not request a hearing thereon within ten days of the date such notice was sent, the license may be forthwith revoked or the denial of the application affirmed. If the licensee requests a hearing before the city commission in regard to such proposed revocation or denial, such hearing shall be held within 21 days after the date of the written request. If the licensee or applicant is a massage establishment, the owner of the premises, according to the latest tax assessment roll, where such establishment is or plans to locate shall also be sent a notice of the hearing by certified mail. 
(b)  Any license issued by the city may be immediately suspended by the mayor if the mayor determines that the licensee, or a person at or upon the licensed location, has violated any city ordinance or state law and that continued operation under the license is contrary to the public health, safety or welfare. A licensee shall have the right to a hearing before the city commission on any license suspension by the mayor. The mayor shall cause a written notice to be personally delivered or sent by certified mail to the licensee, at the address stated in the license, informing the licensee of the suspension and the licensee's right to a hearing, upon request. If the licensee does not file a written request within ten days after receipt of the notice, the city commission may forthwith confirm such suspension, or revoke or reinstate the license. If the licensee requests a hearing before the city commission, the hearing shall be held within 21 days after the date of the written request. Notice of the hearing shall be sent to the licensee by certified mail at the address stated in the license. If the licensee is a massage establishment, the owner of the licensed premises, according to the latest tax assessment roll, shall also be sent a notice of the hearing by certified mail. 
(c)  Both the city and the licensee shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to present evidence on the issue at the hearing. If a license is revoked under this section, the licensee, or a substantially similar or related licensee, shall not be granted a new license, nor shall a license be granted for the same premises for a period of three years from the date of revocation. Upon suspension or revocation of any license or permit, the fee for such license or permit shall not be refunded. The action taken by the city commission shall be final. 
(Code 2004,  26-404; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.769) 
Secs. 26-405-26-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 5. - OPEN AIR BUSINESSES 

Sec. 26-431. - Definitions. 
    The following words terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Short-term open air business shall mean, Uses operated for a period of less than 61 days in a calendar year substantially in the open air or under a tent as an accessory use to an existing principal use conducted on the lot, including, and limited to: 
(1)  Outdoor display and sale of trees, flowers and homemade foods; or 
(2)  Items produced or sold by the existing principal use. 
(Code 2004,  26-431; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.602; Ord. No. 7-06,  1, 4-30-2006) 
Sec. 26-432. - Finding of public purpose. 
    The city commission finds it necessary to establish a procedure to regulate and control the operation of short-term open air businesses for the purpose of promoting the public health, safety and welfare and to preserve the orderly operation of the commercially zoned areas. 
(Code 2004,  26-432; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.601) 
Sec. 26-433. - Districts where permitted. 
    The operation of any short-term open air business within the city shall be considered a permitted accessory use with the approval of the zoning administrator. The site plan review standards of the zoning ordinance shall be used to evaluate the short-term open air business. 
(Code 2004,  26-433; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.603; Ord. No. 7-06,  2, 4-30-2006) 
Sec. 26-434. - Written permission of owner required. 
    Short-term open air business operations require written permission from the owner of the lot, parcel or tract intended for the site of operations. Such written permission shall be upon a form approved by the zoning administrator. 
(Code 2004,  26-434; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.604) 
Sec. 26-435. - Deposit. 
    A deposit or bond as established by resolution of the city commission from time to time shall be made to the city clerk to ensure that clean up of site is accomplished following the expiration of the sales permit. If the clean up is not completed in that time, the deposit is forfeited. 
(Code 2004,  26-435; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.605; Ord. No. 10-05,  1, 7-31-2005) 
Sec. 26-436. - Site plan review. 
    The applicant must submit a simple site plan sketch, to be approved by the zoning administrator, that conforms with applicable sections of the current zoning ordinance (see appendix A to this Code), as determined by the zoning administrator. 
(Code 2004,  26-436; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.606) 
Sec. 26-437. - Signs. 
    Sign display is regulated by the section of the current zoning ordinance (see appendix A to this Code) dealing with the sign restrictions for the district involved. 
(Code 2004,  26-437; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.607) 
Sec. 26-438. - Period of operation. 
    The operation of the short-term open air business may be allowed by the zoning administrator for a period of not more that 30 consecutive days. All short-term sales operations must obtain approval from the zoning administrator and not more that two approvals may be allowed to a business or property within a 12-month period. 
(Code 2004,  26-438; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.608; Ord. No. 7-06,  3, 4-30-2006) 
Sec. 26-439. - Appeals. 
    Where it is alleged that there is an error or misinterpretation in any order, requirement, grant or refusal made by the zoning administrator, an appeal may be made by the applicant to the city commission to hear specific application of such action. The city commission, by a majority vote, may amend, change or modify such action so that it is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of the requirements. 
(Code 2004,  26-439; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.609) 
Secs. 26-440-26-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 6. - BODY ART FACILITIES[3] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Body art facilities, MCL 333.13101 et seq. 

Sec. 26-471. - Adoption of state law by reference. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference, as if fully set out in this article, the provisions of part 131 of Public Act No. 368 of 1978 (MCL 333.13101 et seq.). 
(Code 2004,  26-471-26-503; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.851, 21.855-21.859; Ord. No. 10-13,  1, 10-29-2013) 
Secs. 26-472-26-503. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 7. - ENTERTAINMENT VENUES 

Sec. 26-504. - Purpose. 
    This article is intended to further the protection of public health, safety and welfare by requiring that certain entertainment venues be licensed to ensure that they are operated and maintained so that they cause no excessive demands upon public safety services, nor any risk of harm to the public health, safety, or welfare, or interference with vehicular or pedestrian traffic or parking, or give rise to any public nuisance, disorderly conduct or curfew violation either within the establishment or on or about the adjacent businesses and public streets, alleys, parks, parking facilities, and other areas open to the public. 
(Code 2004,  26-504; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-505. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City license officer or license officer has the meaning set forth in section 26-32. 
    Entertainment venue. Commercial premises which are open to the public, the primary function of which is to offer patrons an opportunity to engage in the following social activities: dancing or similar activity to music, the enjoyment of live or prerecorded music, or the enjoyment of entertainment provided by dancers or other performers. As an incidental function, an entertainment venue may sell and serve food and non-alcoholic beverages to its patrons. The term "entertainment venue" does not include the following: 
(1)  Premises which serve alcoholic liquors as defined by state law; 
(2)  Theaters where the patrons sit in parallel rows of fixed seats; 
(3)  Full service restaurants where the only entertainment provided is incidental to the primary function of serving food; 
(4)  Outdoor performances; 
(5)  A banquet, party or celebration conducted for invited guests which is not otherwise open to the public; 
(6)  Dances or events sponsored and operated by a governmental entity, an educational institution, or nonprofit religious, charitable, benevolent, fraternal, or social organization; or 
(7)  Any adult-oriented establishment subject to article 3 of this chapter. 
    Person. The definition set forth in section 26-32 applies to this article. 
    Venue premises. Any place where an entertainment venue is operated or maintained, including all hallways, bathrooms, parking areas and other adjacent portions of the premises which are accessible to or utilized by the public during operating hours. 
(Code 2004,  26-505; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-506. - Entertainment venue license required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own, lease, operate, manage or maintain an entertainment venue in the city without first obtaining an entertainment venue license from the city. The entertainment venue license is required in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other license, permit or approval required by law, including without limitation, a business license issued pursuant to article 2 of this chapter. For multiuse facilities which include an entertainment venue, a separate and additional license must be issued for the entertainment venue operation. A license shall be obtained for each branch establishment or location of a business. 
(Code 2004,  26-506; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-507. - License not transferable. 
    No license may be transferred by the licensee to any other person. Any transfer or attempt to transfer a license results in the immediate revocation of the license without further action by the city. 
(Code 2004,  26-507; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-508. - License application. 
(a)  An applicant for an entertainment venue license shall provide an operating plan that includes: 
(1)  A written statement setting forth all measures that will be undertaken to ensure that adequate traffic control, crowd protection and security, both inside and outside the venue premises, will be maintained. The statement must provide the number and placement of security personnel, identify areas open to patrons and describe means of maintaining public access to all sidewalks, streets, parking areas, and rights-of-way in the vicinity of the venue premises. 
(2)  A statement of the schedule of operating hours and days. 
(3)  Building and site plans showing the venue premises and, in particular, the specific areas where the license is to be utilized. The plans shall demonstrate adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities and adequate plans for screening. 
(4)  A noise control plan, including any soundproofing required to meet the requirements of section 38-263 and chapter 38 of this Code. 
(5)  Plans for adequate ventilation and sanitation facilities consistent with all applicable codes. 
(b)  An applicant shall provide a written statement affirming whether the applicant, or the applicant's officers, directors, partners or any other person involved in the operation or management of the entertainment venue has been convicted within the preceding five years of any crimes involving firearms, gambling, racketeering, controlled substances, sexual offenses, prostitution, assault, or contributing to the delinquency of a minor. 
(c)  The applicant shall submit documentation of the applicant's interest in the venue premises, including, without limitation, a lease, deed, etc. If the applicant is not the owner of the venue premises, the owner's written consent to the application is required, and the owner shall be named as a co-applicant. 
(d)  The applicant shall agree and consent to the entrance and inspection of the venue premises by a member of the police or fire department, a building inspector or the city license officer. 
(e)  A completed application submitted on forms provided by the city license officer. 
(Code 2004,  26-508; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-509. - Fees. 
    Fees, including an inspection fee, for applications pursuant to this article shall be established by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 2004,  26-509; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-510. - Term, expiration of license. 
    All licenses issued under the terms of this article shall be annual licenses and shall be valid from date of issuance to the following June 30 (unless earlier revoked). Each license shall be reviewed annually with reports submitted by the police chief, the fire chief and the building inspector. After reviewing the reports and other application materials, the license officer shall renew or deny the license in the same manner, and subject to the same standards, as a new license. 
(Code 2004,  26-510; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009) 
Sec. 26-511. - Procedures for issuance or denial of license. 
    After receiving a complete application for an entertainment venue license, the city shall follow the following procedures: 
(1)  The city license officer shall forward copies of the application to appropriate city officials for their comments regarding compliance with regulations under their jurisdiction. The city license officer shall consider all materials and comments submitted and shall issue or deny the license within ten business days after the date on which a completed application was filed unless the applicant agrees to an extension of the time period in writing. 
(2)  An entertainment venue license shall be denied in writing by the city license officer for any one or more of the following grounds: 
a.  If the business premises do not comply with all applicable city ordinances and state laws; 
b.  If the application is incomplete or if it contains any material misrepresentation; 
c.  If the application does not show adequate measures for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare in terms of traffic control, crowd protection and security, both inside and outside the premises as provided in section 26-508(a); 
d.  If the applicant or the applicant's officers, directors, partners or any other person involved in the operation or management of the entertainment venue has been convicted within the preceding five years of any crimes involving firearms, gambling, racketeering, controlled substances, sexual offenses, prostitution, assault, or contributing to the delinquency of a minor; or 
e.  If applicant fails to have an adequate interest in the venue premises in order to ensure compliance with the standards and requirements of this article. 
(3)  An interested person aggrieved by the action of the city license officer in the denial of an application for an entertainment venue license, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of such license, as provided for elsewhere in this article, shall have the right of appeal to the city commission committee of the whole. Such appeal shall be made by filing with the city license officer, within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The city commission committee of the whole shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of the appeal shall be affixed to some structure on the premise and deposited in the United States mail to the last known address of the applicant. 
(Code 2004,  26-511; Ord. No. 1-09,  1, 3-7-2009; Memo of 8-2-2012) 
Sec. 26-512. - Operating rules and regulations. 
    The following operating rules and regulations shall apply to all entertainment venues in the city: 
(1)  The regulations and licensing requirements applicable to all businesses in the city shall apply to entertainment venues. 
(2)  No entertainment venue shall be open to the public after 2:00 a.m. on any day.
