    No person shall destroy, damage or in any manner alter or deface any drinking fountain, public toilet or restroom, or deposit or throw any substance in any public toilet which causes, or may cause, damage to such facility, or put any substance in a water fountain which may in any manner pollute the water therein. For purposes of this section, the terms "drinking fountain" and "public toilet" mean any facilities owned or operated by the city or any governmental unit, as well as facilities owned by private businesses where such facilities are open to, and can be used by, the public. 
(Code 2004,  38-89; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.305(10)) 
Sec. 38-90. - Fire hydrants. 
    No person shall open, or attempt to open, interfere with or damage any fire hydrant, without authority. 
(Code 2004,  38-90; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.305(11)) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377a et seq. 
Sec. 38-91. - Placing signs in public places. 
    No person shall place any sign, advertisement or any other matter upon any lamppost, electric light, railway, telegraph, telephone or other utility pole, fire hydrant, bridge, pavement, sidewalk, crosswalk or public building without the consent and authorization of the appropriate official. This section shall not be construed as preventing any public officer or official from doing any such act for any purpose authorized by the laws of the state or the Charter or ordinances of the city. 
(Code 2004,  38-91; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.305(8)) 
Sec. 38-92. - Placing signs or advertisements without permission of property owner. 
    No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp or paste any sign, advertisement or any other matter upon any house, wall, fence, gate, post or tree without having first obtained the written permission of the owner, agent or occupant of the premises, and without having also obtained any necessary approval or permits. A person who violates any of the provisions of this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 2004,  38-92; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.059(B), 35.064) 
Sec. 38-93. - Operation of vehicles on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a person engaged in city business, to operate any "motor driven vehicle" or "machine," which terms are hereby defined to include, but not be limited to, motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles, over and upon any land owned by the city, except for areas thereof and trails therein which are designated and posted for use by such vehicles and machines by the city. 
(b)  No person 17 years of age or over shall assist, abet or encourage any minor under the age of 17 years to violate any provision of this section. 
(c)  No parent, guardian or other person having the legal care and custody of any minor under the age of 17 years shall knowingly allow, permit or encourage any such minor under the age of 17 years while in his legal custody to violate any provision of this section. 
(d)  No parent, guardian or other person having the legal care and custody of any minor under the age of 17 years shall fail to exercise a sufficient or reasonable control over such minor so as to prevent the minor from violating any provision of this section, when such parent, guardian or other person had knowledge of the fact that such minor had previously committed three or more violations of this section. 
(Code 2004,  38-93; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.201-20.205) 
Secs. 38-94-38-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LARCENY, FRAUD AND RELATED OFFENSES 

Sec. 38-111. - Larceny. 
    No person shall commit the offense of larceny, by stealing, trick or conversion, of the property of another person, any money, goods or chattels, or any bank note, bank bill, bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order or certificate, or any book of accounts for, or concerning, money or goods due, to become due or to be delivered, or any deed or writing counting the conveyance of land or any other valuable contract in force, or any receipt, release or defeasance, or any writ, process or public record. 
(Code 2004,  38-111; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(1); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(1)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Larceny generally, MCL 750.356 et seq. 
Sec. 38-112. - Theft of services. 
    No person shall, knowingly and willfully, defraud any taxicab, boardinghouse, hotel, motel, inn, restaurant, gas station, service station or cafe by procuring any transportation service, food, drink, entertainment, room, accommodation, gas, oil or repair with the intent not to pay for such goods or service. This section shall not be interpreted to conflict with the right of any person to dispute the amount, type or quality of goods or services for as long as the person gives notice of the dispute, provides identification of his name and address and the notice of the dispute is given before leaving the scene. 
(Code 2004,  38-112; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(9); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(9)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Defrauding hotels, innkeepers, etc., MCL 750.292. 
Sec. 38-113. - Fraud generally. 
    No person shall obtain, or attempt to obtain, money, goods, property or services by fraud, trick or false pretenses. 
(Code 2004,  38-113; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(2); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(2)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- False pretenses and false representation, MCL 750.218 et seq. 
Sec. 38-114. - Retail fraud. 
(a)  In this section, the term "retail fraud" means that a person does one or more of the following: 
(1)  While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale. 
(2)  While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale. 
(3)  With the intent to defraud, obtains, or attempts to obtain, money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for or belongs to the store. 
(b)  No person shall engage in retail fraud. 
(Code 2004,  38-114; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(11); Ord. No. 06-02,  1(1(13)), 3(10(11)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Retail fraud, MCL 750.356c, 750.356d. 
Sec. 38-115. - Obtaining telephone service by fraud. 
    No person shall knowingly obtain, or attempt to obtain, telephone service or the transmission of a telephone message by the use of any false or fictitious telephone credit number or telephone number of another person without the authority of the person to whom such telephone credit number or telephone number was issued. 
(Code 2004,  38-115; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(3); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(3)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Obtaining telecommunications services with intent to avoid charge, MCL 750.219a. 
Sec. 38-116. - Embezzlement. 
    No person shall, as the agent, servant or employee of another person, or as the trustee, bailee or custodian of the property of another person, or of any partnership, voluntary association, or public or private corporation, or of the state, or of any county, city, village, township or school district within the state, fraudulently dispose of or convert to his own use, or take or secrete with the intent to convert to his own use, without the consent of his principal, any money or other personal property of his principal which shall have come to his possession or shall be under his charge or control by virtue of his being such agent, servant, employee, trustee, bailee or custodian. 
(Code 2004,  38-116; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(6); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(6)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.174. 
Sec. 38-117. - Receiving stolen property. 
    No person shall buy, receive, possess, conceal or aid in the concealment of stolen, embezzled or converted money, goods or property, knowing the money, goods or property to be stolen, embezzled or converted. 
(Code 2004,  38-117; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(4); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(4)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Receiving stolen property, MCL 750.535. 
Sec. 38-118. - Failure to return rented property. 
    No person shall refuse or willfully neglect to return a motor vehicle, trailer or other tangible property which he has on a rental or lease basis under any agreement in writing providing for the property's return to a particular place at a particular time. 
(Code 2004,  38-118; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(5); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(5)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Failure to return rented property, MCL 750.362a. 
Sec. 38-119. - False orders for deliveries of food. 
    No person shall telephone in a false order to any food delivery service or a false request to any service business and request that food be delivered to a location or that services be rendered at a particular location. 
(Code 2004,  38-119; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(8); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(8)), 4-1-2002) 
Sec. 38-120. - Accessing confidential information. 
    No person shall, by use of a computer, telephone or other electronic or mechanical device, obtain or gain access to any database, confidential records or other information not his own, without permission of the owner or keeper of such information. 
(Code 2004,  38-120; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(7); Ord. No. 06-02,  3(10(7)), 4-1-2002) 
Sec. 38-121. - Theft detection tags or shielding devices. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Theft detection shielding device means a bag, container or other device laminated, coated or constructed to shield merchandise from detection, or to otherwise prevent its detection, by an electronic or magnetic theft alarm sensor. 
    Theft detection tag removal device means a device designed or capable of use to remove a theft prevention sensor tag from clothing or other merchandise. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly possess a theft detection shielding device, a theft detection tag removal device or any tool, implement or device which has been designed or adapted for breaking open any building or motor vehicle, or for starting the engine of a motor vehicle without the regular key, or for removing sensor tags from property for sale at retail, with the intent to use or employ such device, tool or implement for the purpose of willfully removing property not his own. 
(Code 2004,  38-121; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.310(10); Ord. No. 06-02,  1(1(16), (17)), 3(10(10)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.360a. 
Secs. 38-122-38-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISHONORED CHECKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dishonored checks, MCL 750.131 et seq. 

Sec. 38-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Address of record means the address that appears on the check or the last known address of record with the secretary of state at the time the check was presented for payment of goods or services. 
    Check means any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository. 
    Dishonored means any: 
(1)  Check, draft or order drawn or written on any account, or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, without sufficient funds for the payment thereof when presentation is made to the drawee. 
(2)  Check, draft or order drawn or written on any account which has been closed with or by the bank or other depository upon which it is drawn. 
    Expenses of dishonored check response means the direct and reasonable cost incurred by the city, or by a private person or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city, when making a dishonored check response, including the cost of providing the police, city attorney and/or administrative services in response to any dishonored check. The costs further include all of the salaries and wages of the city personnel and/or contractors responding to the incident, all salaries and wages of the personnel and contractors engaged in investigation, supervision and report preparation, and all costs connected with the administration and provision of any prosecution of the person causing the incident. 
(Code 2004,  38-141; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.771, 20.792) 
Sec. 38-142. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person shall, with the intent to defraud, make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, knowing, at the time of the making, drawing, uttering or delivering, that the maker or drawer does not have sufficient funds in or credit with the bank or other depository for the payment of the check, draft or order, in full, upon its presentation, of the amount payable in such check, draft or order in any amount. 
(b)  No person shall, with the intent to defraud, make, draw, utter or deliver any check, draft or order for the payment of money, to apply on account or otherwise, upon any bank or other depository, unless the person has sufficient funds for payment thereof when presentment is due to the drawee in any amount, except where the lack of funds is due to garnishment, attachment, levy or other lawful cause, and such fact was not known to the person who made, drew, uttered or delivered the instrument at the time thereof. 
(c)  As against the maker or drawer thereof, the making, drawing, uttering or delivering of a check, draft or order, payment of which is refused by the drawee, when presented in the usual course of business, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and of knowledge of insufficient funds in or credit with such bank or other depository, provided such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee thereof the amount due thereon, together with all cost and protest fees, within five business days after receiving notice that such check, draft or order has not been paid by the drawee. 
(d)  Where such check, draft or order is protested on the ground of insufficiency of funds or credit, the notice of protest thereof shall be admissible as proof of presentation, nonpayment and protest, and shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and knowledge of insufficient funds or credit with such bank or other depository. 
(Code 2004,  38-142; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.772) 
Sec. 38-143. - Liability for dishonored check response. 
(a)  Findings. The city finds that a significant number of checks are written and dishonored within its geographical boundaries, causing serious financial loss and hardship to citizens and merchants therein. In addition, the city finds that the financial loss and hardship incurred by its citizens and merchants seriously impacts the stream of commerce and the general public by causing increases in the costs of goods and services. As a result of these determinations, a greater operational and financial burden is placed upon the city's police and legal services by persons who are placing dishonored checks into the stream of commerce. 
(b)  Person responsible. Any person is liable for the expense of a dishonored check response if such person proximately causes any incident resulting in a dishonored check response. 
(c)  Presumptions. 
(1)  For the purpose of this section, a person is presumed to be the proximate cause of an incident if such person makes, draws, utters or delivers any dishonored check or causes, directly or indirectly, a check to become dishonored. 
(2)  For the purpose of this section, a person is presumed to have acted with intent to defraud if such person shall not have paid the drawer thereof the amount due thereon, together with all costs and protest fees, including the fees assessed under this section, within five business days after receiving notice, by first class mail to the last known address of record, that such check, draft or order has not been paid by the drawee. 
(d)  Charges against person. To the extent permitted by law, the expenses of a dishonored check response shall be a charge against the person liable for the expense under this section. The charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the city for incurring those costs in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract, expressed or implied. 
(e)  Cost recovery schedule. The city commission shall by resolution adopt a schedule of costs included within the expense of a dishonored check response. The schedule shall be available to the public from either the city clerk, treasurer or police department. 
(f)  Billing. The chief administrative officer or his designee may submit a bill for the dishonored check response by first class mail to the last known address of record or personal service to the person liable for the expenses as enumerated under this section. The bill shall require full payment within 30 consecutive days from the date of service. Service by mail shall be effective upon depositing the bill in a United States Postal Service receptacle. In no event shall billing be permitted after one year from the last expense incurred. 
(g)  Failure to pay; procedure to recover cost. Any person described in this section as liable for the expense of a dishonored check response, who fails to pay the bill within 30 consecutive days of service, shall be considered in default. In case of default, the city may commence civil suit to recover the expenses and any costs allowed by law. 
(Code 2004,  38-143; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.791, 20.793) 
Secs. 38-144-38-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 4. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-161. - Endangering safety of assemblies. 
    No person shall incite or cause, or attempt to incite or cause, any assembled group of persons to act in a manner that is likely to, or does, endanger the safety of another person or property. 
(Code 2004,  38-161; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(6)) 
Sec. 38-162. - Abandoned refrigerators and airtight containers. 
    No person shall have in his possession, outside of any building, structure or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other similar airtight container of any kind, large enough for a child to enter, which has a snap latch or other locking device thereon, without first removing the snap latch, other locking device or the doors from such icebox, refrigerator or other such airtight container. 
(Code 2004,  38-162; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.053) 
State Law reference- Abandoned or unattended icebox or refrigerator, MCL 750.493d. 
Sec. 38-163. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following shall apply: 
(1)  "Act 256" means the Michigan Fireworks Safety Act, Public Act No. 256 of 2011 (MCL 28.451 et seq.). 
(2)  For all purposes, the words and phrases in the section shall have the same meaning as provided for in Act 256. 
(b)  Compliance with applicable ordinances and codes. Unless otherwise provided herein, a retailer or wholesaler of fireworks located within the city must comply with the requirements of the city's zoning ordinance, as well as all building codes and regulations. 
(c)  Use of consumer fireworks prohibited. 
(1)  On a day other than the day preceding, the day of, and the day after a national holiday, no person shall ignite, discharge, or use consumer fireworks in the city. 
(2)  On the day preceding, the day of, and the day after a national holiday, no person shall ignite, discharge, or use consumer fireworks between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., consistent with Act 256. 
A person who violates this subsection (c) shall be responsible for a municipal civil infraction and subject to a fine of $500.00. 
(d)  Firework safety. No person shall recklessly endanger the life, health, safety, or well-being of any person or property by the ignition, discharge, or use of consumer fireworks. 
(e)  Possession by or sale to minor. 
(1)  No person shall sell fireworks to a person under the age of 18 years. 
(2)  No person under the age of 18 years shall use, possess, explode or cause to explode any consumer fireworks within the city except while in the presence and under the control of a parent, guardian or other responsible adult. 
(3)  No person under the age of 18 years shall buy, purchase, acquire or obtain any consumer fireworks within the city. 
(f)  Use of fireworks. No person shall use consumer fireworks or low-impact fireworks while under the influence of alcoholic liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of alcoholic liquor and a controlled substance. As used in this subsection: 
(1)  Alcoholic liquor means that term as defined in section 1d of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Act 300 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1949, as amended from time to time. 
(2)  Controlled substance means that term as defined in section 8b of the Michigan Vehicle Code, Act 300 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1949, as amended from time to time. 
(g)  Violations, fines and penalties. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by up to 90 days in jail and/or a fine up to $500.00. 
(Code 2004,  38-163; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(5); Ord. No. 1-12,  1, 5-23-2012; Ord. No. 4-12,  1, 6-24-2012; Ord. No. 8-13,  1, 2, 6-30-2013) 
Sec. 38-164. - Placement of glass, nails or pointed objects. 
    No person shall maliciously throw or place glass, nails, tacks or other dangerous pointed or edged substances in or on any beach, highway, public property or private walk or driveway not his own. 
(Code 2004,  38-164; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.313(8)) 
State Law reference- Littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 
Sec. 38-165. - Noxious and offensive odors. 
    No person shall permit matter to putrefy or decay, or be burned so as to cause, nor in any other manner cause or create, noxious or offensive odors, fumes or gases that imperil the health or safety of any person or so as to disturb, unnecessarily and without reasonable cause, the comfort of any person within the city. A person who violates this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 2004,  38-165; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.055, 35.064) 
Secs. 38-166-38-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEAPONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Firearms and weapons, MCL 750.222 et seq.; local regulation of firearms, MCL 123.1101 et seq. 

Sec. 38-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bow means a device for propelling an arrow from a string drawn, held, and released by hand where the force used to hold the string in the drawn position is provided by the archer's muscles. 
    Dangerous weapon means any weapon likely to produce death or great bodily injury, or a weapon which, in the manner in which it is used, or attempted to be used, endangers life or inflicts great bodily harm. 
    Firearm means any weapon or device from which is propelled any missile, projectile, bullet, shot, pellet or other mass by means of explosives, compressed air or gas or by means of springs, levers or other mechanical devices which weapon or device shall be capable by the discharge of any such propelled missile, projectile, bullet, shot, pellet or other mass of inflicting personal injury or death upon any person, except any smooth bore rifle or hand gun designed and manufactured exclusively for propelling on any one manipulation of the trigger, a single BB, not exceeding .177 caliber, by means of a spring, gas or air. 
(Code 2004,  38-191, 38-199; Ord. No. 18-67,  1, 9-24-1967; Ord. No. 14-90,  1, 7-15-1990; Ord. No. 06-02,  1(1(4)), 4-1-2002) 
Sec. 38-192. - Discharge. 
    No person shall, without authority by law, discharge any firearm, air rifle, air pistol, paintball gun or other dangerous weapon within or into the city, except at a city approved facility established for such purpose. This section shall not apply to the discharge of blank ammunition as part of a city-approved event, parade or funeral ceremony. 
(Code 2004,  38-192; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(7)) 
Sec. 38-193. - Possession of martial arts weapons. 
    No person shall possess weapons of the martial arts without a legitimate cause which is related to the person's occupation or business and except on the person's own private property. 
(Code 2004,  38-193; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(5)) 
Sec. 38-194. - Sale or possession of knife having mechanical opening device. 
    No person shall sell, offer to sell or have in his possession any knife having the appearance of a pocket knife, the blade of which can be opened by manipulating a button, applying pressure on a handle or other mechanical contrivance, except under such conditions as are provided by state law. 
(Code 2004,  38-194; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.226a. 
Sec. 38-195. - Carrying concealed weapon. 
(a)  No person shall carry a dagger, knife, dirk, stiletto, double-edged nonfolding stabbing instrument of any length or other dangerous weapon, except hunting knifes adapted and carried as such, concealed on or about his person or in a motor vehicle, concealed or otherwise, operated or occupied by such person, except in his dwelling house or place of business, or on other land possessed by such person. 
(b)  No person shall carry a pistol concealed on or about his person, or, whether concealed or otherwise, in a vehicle operated or occupied by him, without a license as provided by law, except in his dwelling place or place of business, or, if licensed, carry a pistol in a place or manner inconsistent with any restrictions upon such license. 
(Code 2004,  38-195; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(2), (3)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.227. 
Sec. 38-196. - Public possession. 
    No person shall, without authority by law, possess or brandish any firearm, air rifle, air pistol, paintball gun or other dangerous weapon in any public street, park or place open to, or within the view of, the general public. 
(Code 2004,  38-196; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(8)) 
Sec. 38-197. - Weapons in vehicles. 
    No person shall possess, within the passenger compartment of any motor vehicle, any firearm, air rifle, air pistol, paintball gun or other dangerous weapon in or about any public street, park or public place unless the weapon is licensed as required by law or is unloaded and securely wrapped or encased; provided, however, that such prohibition shall not apply to a law enforcement officer in the lawful performance of his duty. 
(Code 2004,  38-197; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(4)) 
Sec. 38-198. - Throwing objects. 
    No person shall wrongfully throw or propel any snowball, paintball, missile or object from any moving vehicle or toward any person, vehicle or property of another person. 
(Code 2004,  38-198; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.312(6)) 
State Law reference- Throwing stone or missile at train or automobile, MCL 750.394. 
Sec. 38-199. - Reserved. 
Sec. 38-200. - Areas defined. 
(a)  No firearm shall be discharged at any time within the city limits except when properly discharged on a properly licensed firing range. A BB gun, as referred to in section 38-191, may be discharged in any place or manner permitted under the laws of the state. 
(b)  No bow and arrow shall be discharged at any time within the city, except when properly discharged on an indoor range or, when properly discharged outdoors on property consisting of not-less-than five contiguous acres, the narrow side of which is not less than 450 feet, owned by one or more persons who, by mutual written agreement, provide their property for such purpose; provided, however, that no bow and arrow shall be discharged within 450 feet of a house, garage, barn or any commercial establishment or any other occupied building, except by written consent of the owner. 
(Code 2004,  38-200; Ord. No. 18-67,  1, 9-24-1967; Ord. No. 14-90,  1, 7-15-1990) 
Secs. 38-201-38-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 5. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-231. - Disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall create or unlawfully engage in any disturbance, fight or quarrel in any public place, except in reasonable self-defense when attacked without reasonable provocation or in reasonable defense of another who was so attacked. 
(Code 2004,  38-231; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(1)) 
Sec. 38-232. - Disturbing the peace. 
    No person shall disturb the public peace and quiet by loud, boisterous or vulgar conduct or language. 
(Code 2004,  38-232; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(2)) 
Sec. 38-233. - Disturbing meetings. 
    No person shall disturb or unreasonably interfere with any service of worship or any other assembly gathered for lawful purposes. 
(Code 2004,  38-233; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(4)) 
State Law reference- Disturbing religious worship or other meetings, MCL 750.169, 750.170. 
Sec. 38-234. - Obstructing public passages. 
    No person shall, without proper authority, conduct himself in any public place so as to obstruct the free and uninterrupted passage of the public. 
(Code 2004,  38-234; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(3)) 
Sec. 38-235. - Begging and soliciting. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings provided in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accosting means approaching or speaking to a person in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon his person, or upon property in his immediate possession. 
    Ask, beg or solicit mean and include, without limitation, the spoken, written or printed word or such other acts as are conducted in furtherance of the purpose of obtaining donations. 
    Forcing oneself upon the company of another means continuing to ask, beg or solicit from a person after that person has made a negative response, blocking the passage of the individual addressed, or otherwise engaging in conduct which could reasonably be construed as intended to compel or force a person to accede to demands. 
(b)  Except to the extent otherwise expressly permitted by law, it shall be unlawful for any person to solicit money or other things of value: 
(1)  On private property if the owner, tenant or lawful occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property or has posted a sign clearly indicating that solicitations are not welcome on the property; 
(2)  Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from any public toilet facility; 
(3)  Within 15 feet of an automated teller machine, provided that when an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the automated teller machine facility; 
(4)  Within 15 feet of any pay telephone, provided that when a pay telephone is located within a telephone booth or other facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the telephone booth or facility; 
(5)  Within any public transportation vehicle, or within 15 feet of any bus stop, taxi stand or rapid transit stop; 
(6)  From any operator of a motor vehicle that is in traffic on a public street; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to services rendered in connection with emergency repairs requested by the owner or passengers of such vehicle; 
(7)  From any person who is waiting in line for entry to any building, public or private, including, but not limited to, any residence, business or athletic facility; or 
(8)  Within 15 feet of the entrance or exit from a building, public or private, including, but not limited to, any residence, business or athletic facility. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing herein shall be interpreted to prohibit related parties from soliciting money or other things of value from one another. 
Organizations exempted by law from this section shall register with the clerk's office and establish that they meet the requirements of MCL 257.676b(2) and individuals soliciting on behalf of such organizations within a public right of way may not be nearer the roadway than two feet of the curb of a two-lane road or the right-hand curb lane of a multi-lane road. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit money or other things of value by: 
(1)  Accosting another; or 
(2)  Forcing oneself upon the company of another. 
(Code 2004,  38-235; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.304(4); Ord. No. 06-02,  2(4(4)), 4-1-2002; Ord. No. 9-13,  2, 9-21-2013; Ord. No. 13-18,  1, 11-12-2018) 
State Law reference- Begging, MCL 750.167(1)(h). 
Sec. 38-236. - Unsanitary acts. 
    No person shall expectorate, urinate, defecate or perform any other act which creates a hazardous, unsanitary or deleterious condition in any public place or upon the property of any other person. This subsection shall not apply to the proper use of public restroom facilities. 
(Code 2004,  38-236; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.313(5)) 
Secs. 38-237-38-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NOISE 

Sec. 38-261. - Penalties. 
    A person who violates any of the provisions of this division is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 2004,  38-261; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.064) 
Sec. 38-262. - Exceptions. 
    The terms of prohibitions in this division shall not apply or be enforced against the following: 
(1)  Emergency vehicles. Any police, fire, public utility vehicle or ambulance while being operated in a manner authorized by law. 
(2)  Highway maintenance and construction. Excavations or repairs of bridges, streets, highways or within other public rights-of-way performed by or on behalf of any governmental agency, franchise or authorized telecommunication permittee during the night when the public safety renders it impossible to perform such work during the working day. 
(Code 2004,  38-262; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.057) 
Sec. 38-263. - Loud noises. 
(a)  No person shall permit or allow any loud noise, electrical, mechanical, human or animal in origin, to be emitted from any place occupied or controlled by him so as to unnecessarily disturb, without reasonable cause, the quiet, comfort or repose of any person. 
(b)  No person shall create any loud noise in such a manner as to unnecessarily disturb, without reasonable cause, the quiet, comfort or repose of any person between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except as allowed by permit issued by the city. 
(Code 2004,  38-263; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(8), (10)) 
Sec. 38-264. - Engine exhaust. 
    The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, internal combustion engine or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which effectively prevents loud or explosive noises therefrom, is unlawful. 
(Code 2004,  38-264; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.056(G)) 
Sec. 38-265. - Construction noises. 
    The erection (including excavation therefor), demolition, alteration or repair of any building, and the excavation of streets and highways at any time on Sundays, and except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. on other days, is unlawful. The mayor, upon recommendation of the department of public works, may grant temporary exceptions to this section in writing. 
(Code 2004,  38-265; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.056(H)) 
Sec. 38-266. - Handling merchandise. 
    The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading and unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. is unlawful. 
(Code 2004,  38-266; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.056(I)) 
Sec. 38-267. - Sound amplifiers. 
    The outdoor use of any loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other electrical or mechanical device intended to increase the volume of sound, whether stationary or mounted on a vehicle, without first having obtained a permit from the chief of police, upon consultation with the community development director, is unlawful. Such permit shall be issued upon written application being made describing the intended use of such equipment and upon a determination that the described use, at the times and places indicated, will not unreasonably disturb the quiet, comfort, repose or safety of any person. The reason for any application's denial shall be provided in writing and may be appealed in writing to the city commission within ten days of the decision. 
(Code 2004,  38-267; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.307(8), 35.056(K)) 
Sec. 38-268. - Sound systems in vehicles. 
    No person operating or in control of a stopped or moving motor vehicle shall operate or permit operation of a sound system in the vehicle so as to produce sound that is audible at a distance of 50 feet from the vehicle between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., or audible at a distance of 25 feet from the vehicle between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.; provided, however, this section shall not apply to the sound system of a police, fire or other public service vehicle while the public service vehicle is being used in the performance of public service work. 
(Code 2004,  38-268; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.056(M)) 
Secs. 38-269-38-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 6. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC MORALS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-301. - Prostitution. 
    No person shall engage in prostitution or solicit or accost any person for the purpose of inducing the commission of any illegal act. 
(Code 2004,  38-301; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.309(1)) 
State Law reference- Prostitution, MCL 750.448 et seq. 
Sec. 38-302. - Gambling. 
(a)  No person shall engage in gambling or any game of chance for money unless otherwise permitted by law. 
(b)  No person shall keep, maintain or permit the use of a gambling room, table or equipment, or any policy or pool tickets to be used for gambling on any premises occupied or controlled by him. 
(Code 2004,  38-302; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.309(2), (5)) 
State Law reference- Gambling, MCL 750.301 et seq. 
Sec. 38-303. - Public nudity, indecent exposure, swimming nude. 
(a)  In this section, the term "public nudity" means knowingly or intentionally displaying in a public place, or from a private place in such a manner as to allow the display to be seen from a public place, or for payment or promise of payment by any person, including, but not limited to, payment or promise for payment of an admission fee, any individual's genitals or anus with less than a fully opaque covering, or a female individual's breast without less than a fully opaque covering of the nipple and areola. Such term does not include any of the following: 
(1)  A woman's breastfeeding of a baby, whether or not the nipple or areola is exposed during or incidental to the feeding. 
(2)  "Material" as defined in section 2 of Public Act No. 343 of 1984 (MCL 752.362). 
(3)  "Sexually explicit visual material" as defined in section 3 of Public Act No. 33 of 1978 (MCL 722.673). 
(b)  No person shall: 
(1)  Engage in public nudity. 
(2)  Make any indecent exposure of his person in a public place or knowingly do so in a private place where the exhibition or exposure may be viewed by a person located in a public place. 
(3)  Swim or bathe in the nude in any public place or on private property without the specific permission of the owner of such property. 
(Code 2004,  38-303; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.313(1), (2), (4); Ord. No. 06-02,  1(1(11)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Indecent exposure, MCL 750.335a; power to punish public nudity, MCL 117.5h. 
Secs. 38-304-38-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ALCOHOL AND CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, MCL 333.7101 et seq.; Michigan liquor control code of 1998. 

Subdivision 1. - In General 

Sec. 38-321. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Controlled substance means a drug, substance or precursor which has been designated as a controlled substance by any federal law or state statute. 
    Drug means any drug or other substance, the sale, distribution and/or possession of which is prohibited or restricted by federal or state law. 
(Code 2004,  38-321; Ord. No. 06-02,  1(1(3), (6)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, MCL 333.7101 et seq. 
Sec. 38-322. - Sale, manufacture, use of controlled substances. 
(a)  No person shall use, knowingly possess, manufacture, plant, grow, cultivate or deliver to another person, any controlled substance. This section shall not be interpreted to prohibit a police officer engaged in lawful duties, a person acting pursuant to a license granted by the United States or the state, or a person acting at the lawful direction of a licensed medical doctor or dentist. 
(b)  In addition to the fines, costs, terms of imprisonment or terms of probation, a person convicted under this section shall be subject to the driver's license sanctions authorized by state statute. 
(c)  When a person, who has not previously been convicted of an offense under this division, a similar ordinance of another municipality or any similar state statute or statute of the United States, pleads guilty, the court, with the consent of the prosecuting attorney, without entering a judgment of guilt, may defer further proceedings and place the individual on probation under such terms and conditions as are authorized by state statute. 
(Code 2004,  38-322; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(10)) 
State Law reference- Controlled substances, MCL 333.7101 et seq. 
Sec. 38-323. - Selling drugs without license. 
    No person shall sell, give or furnish any drug to any person without first obtaining a license to sell, give or furnish such drug. 
(Code 2004,  38-323; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(2)) 
State Law reference- Licensing of sale of controlled substances, MCL 333.7303 et seq. 
Sec. 38-324. - Sale of alcohol to intoxicated persons. 
    No person shall sell, give or furnish any alcoholic liquor to any person who appears, or is reasonably suspected, to be drunk or intoxicated. 
(Code 2004,  38-324; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(3)) 
State Law reference- Sale to intoxicated persons, MCL 436.1707. 
Sec. 38-325. - Public intoxication. 
    No person shall be intoxicated or under the influence of an alcoholic liquor or under the influence of any drug or any combination of alcoholic liquors and drugs in any public place and either directly endanger the safety of another person or the property of another person, or act in a manner that causes or creates a public disturbance. 
(Code 2004,  38-325; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(1)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.167(1)(e); local ordinances punishing public intoxication, MCL 330.1286. 
Sec. 38-326. - Operation of machinery while under the influence. 
    No person shall knowingly allow or permit any other person to operate a piece of machinery owned or controlled by him when he knows, or should reasonably know, that the other person is intoxicated or under the influence of an alcoholic liquor or a controlled substance. 
(Code 2004,  38-326; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(8)) 
State Law reference- Driving while intoxicated, MCL 257.625 et seq.; operation of vessel under influence of alcohol, MCL 324.80176 et seq.; operation of off-road vehicle under influence of alcohol, MCL 324.81134 et seq.; operation of snowmobiles under influence of alcohol, MCL 324.82127 et seq. 
Sec. 38-327. - Public consumption or possession of alcohol. 
(a)  No person shall consume, possess or knowingly have under his control any open container of an alcoholic liquor in any public park, on public school property or upon any public street or public sidewalk. This subsection shall not apply if the alcoholic liquor is consumed or possessed exclusively within an area which is currently licensed for sale or consumption by the state liquor control commission, and if the person is otherwise lawfully entitled to consume or possess the alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  To the extent otherwise permitted by law, alcohol may only be possessed or consumed on city-owned property consistent with and subject to a permit issued by the city. 
(Code 2004,  38-327; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(9); Ord. No. 8-12,  1, 9-26-2012) 
Sec. 38-328. - Open house parties. 
    No person shall permit or allow any premises owned or controlled by him to be used or occupied by persons engaged in the unlawful use of an alcoholic liquor or controlled substance. 
(Code 2004,  38-328; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(11)) 
State Law reference- Prohibited conduct by person having control of real property, MCL 750.141a. 
Secs. 38-329-38-350. - Reserved. 
Subdivision 2. - Drug Paraphernalia[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Drug paraphernalia, MCL 333.7451 et seq. 

Sec. 38-351. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Drug paraphernalia means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance as provided for in the Michigan Public Health Code (MCL 333.1101 et seq.). Such term includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Kits used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing or harvesting any species of plant which is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived; 
(2)  Kits used, intended for use or designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing controlled substances; 
(3)  Isomerization devices used, intended for use or designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is a controlled substance; 
(4)  Testing equipment used, intended for use or designed for use in identifying or analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of controlled substances; 
(5)  Scales and balances used, intended for use or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances; 
(6)  Diluents and adulterants, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose and lactose, used, intended for use or designed for use in cutting controlled substances; 
(7)  Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining, marijuana/marihuana; 
(8)  Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended for use or designed for use in compounding controlled substances; 
(9)  Capsules, balloons, envelopes and other containers used, intended for use or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances; 
(10)  Containers and other objects used, intended for use or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances; 
(11)  Hypodermic syringes, needles and other objects used, intended for use or designed for use in parenterally injecting controlled substances into the human body; 
(12)  Objects used, intended for use or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing marijuana/marihuana, cocaine, hashish or hashish oil into the human body, such as: 
a.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic or ceramic pipes, with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads or punctured metal bowls; 
b.  Water pipes; 
c.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
d.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
e.  Roach clips, which are objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana/marihuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand; 
f.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; 
g.  Chamber pipes; 
h.  Carburetor pipes; 
i.  Electric pipes; 
j.  Air-driven pipes; 
k.  Chillums; 
l.  Bongs; 
m.  Ice pipes or chillers. 
(Code 2004,  38-351; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.701) 
Sec. 38-352. - Exclusions. 
    This subdivision does not apply to: 
(1)  A police officer who, in the course of his duties, is required to perform certain acts in investigating illegal drug traffic. 
(2)  A person for whom marijuana/marihuana has been prescribed by a physician, duly licensed by the state. 
(3)  A person who, in the course of his business, is required to handle such items. 
(Code 2004,  38-352; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.704) 
Sec. 38-353. - Possession. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, or possess with the intent to use, drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of this subdivision. 
(Code 2004,  38-353; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.702) 
Sec. 38-354. - Manufacture or delivery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver, or possess with the intent to deliver, drug paraphernalia, knowing, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that it will be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of this subdivision. 
(Code 2004,  38-354; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.703) 
Sec. 38-355. - Advertisement. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill or other publication any advertisement, knowing, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that the purpose of the advertisement, in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of objects designed or intended for use as drug paraphernalia. 
(Code 2004,  38-355; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.706) 
Secs. 38-356-38-360. - Reserved. 
Subivision 2. - Chemical Inhalants[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1-18,  1, adopted Jan. 8, 2018, set out provisions adding  38-391-38-393. To preserve the existing  38-361-38-363, and at the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein as  38-361-38-363. 

Sec. 38-361. - Generally. 
    No person shall, for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, hallucination, elation, euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction, or dulling of the senses or nervous system, intentionally inhale, ingest, apply, use, possess, or introduce any chemical agent into their respiratory or circulatory system. This shall not prohibit the inhalation or application of anesthesia for medical or dental purposes or the use of tobacco products or vapor pipes to the extent permitted by law. 
    No person shall knowingly use or possess with intent to use inhalant paraphernalia to inhale, ingest, apply, use, possess, or introduce any chemical agent into their respiratory or circulatory system in violation of this subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1-18,  1, 1-8-2018) 
Sec. 38-362. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chemical agent means any substance containing a toxic chemical or organic solvent or both, having the property of releasing toxic vapors. The term includes, but is not limited to, glue, acetone, toluene, carbon tetrachloride, hydrocarbons, and hydrocarbon derivatives. 
    Inhalant paraphernalia means equipment or materials of any kind that is intended for use in inhaling, ingesting, or otherwise introducing into the human body a chemical agent. The term includes a tube, balloon, bag, fabric, bottle, or other container used to concentrate or hold in suspension a chemical agent or vapors of the chemical agent. 
(Ord. No. 1-18,  1, 1-8-2018) 
Sec. 38-363. - Sale of devices containing nitrous oxide. 
    A person shall not sell or otherwise distribute to another person any device that contains any quantity of nitrous oxide or sell or otherwise distribute a device to dispense nitrous oxide for the purpose of causing a condition of intoxication, euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction, or dulling of the senses or nervous system. This section does not apply to nitrous oxide that has been denatured or otherwise rendered unfit for human consumption or to any of the following: 
(1)  A person licensed under the Food Processing Act of 1977, 1978 PA 328, MCL 289.801-289.810, or Chapter VII of the Food Law of 2000, 2000 PA 92, MCL 289.7101-289.7137, who sells or otherwise distributes the device as a grocery product. 
(2)  A person engaged in the business of selling or distributing catering supplies only or food processing equipment only, or selling or distributing compressed gases for industrial or medical use who sells or otherwise distributes the device in the course of that business. 
(3)  A pharmacist, pharmacist intern, or pharmacy as defined in Section 17707 of the Public Health Code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.17707, who dispenses the device in the course of his or her duties as a pharmacist or pharmacist intern or as a pharmacy. 
(4)  A health care professional. 
(Ord. No. 1-18,  1, 1-8-2018) 
Secs. 38-364-38-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 7. - OFFENSES INVOLVING MINORS OR UNDERAGE PERSONS 

Sec. 38-391. - Truancy. 
(a)  In this section, the term: 
(1)  School means any public, private or parochial preelementary, elementary (grades K-6), secondary (grades 7-12), high school or combination thereof. 
(2)  Truant means a person between six and 16 years of age who is out of school during regular school hours. 
(b)  No person shall: 
(1)  Be a truant and remain in any public place, unless such activity is part of an organized school program or such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(2)  Having care or custody of a minor, knowingly permit a person between the age of six and 16 years to violate this section. 
(Code 2004,  38-391; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.313(9); Ord. No. 06-02,  1(1(14), (18)), 4-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Compulsory school attendance, MCL 380.1561 et seq. 
Sec. 38-392. - Curfew for underage persons. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person: 
(1)  Under the age of 12 years to be in any public place between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  Who is 12 years of age or older and less than 16 years of age to be in any public place between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(3)  Who is 16 years of age or older and less than 17 years of age to be in any public place between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (a) of this section that the person was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the person's parent or guardian or an adult designated by the person's parent or guardian; 
(2)  On an errand at the direction of the person's parent or guardian or an adult designated by the person's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency. In this subsection, the term "emergency" means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. Such term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, natural disaster, automobile accident or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life; 
(6)  Attending an official school, religious or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the person, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the person; 
(7)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly; or 
(8)  Married, or had been married or is an emancipated minor removed in accordance with law. 
(c)  No person shall assist, aid, abet, allow, permit or encourage any person to violate subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 2004,  38-392; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.341-20.346; Ord. No. 4-09,  1, 8-28-2009) 
State Law reference- Curfew for underage persons, MCL 722.751 et seq. 
Sec. 38-393. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- This section pertaining to sale of alcohol to underage persons was deleted as covered by Code  6-1. It was derived from Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(6) and Code 2004,  38-393. 
Sec. 38-394. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- This section pertaining to false representation of age in order to obtain alcohol was deleted as covered by Code  6-1. It was derived from Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(7) and Code 2004,  38-394. 
Sec. 38-395. - Adoption of youth tobacco act. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference the youth tobacco act, Public Act No. 31 of 1915 (MCL 722.641 et seq.), as if fully set out herein. 
(Code 2004,  38-395; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.306(12)-(14)) 
Sec. 38-396. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- This section pertaining to purchase, consumption or possession of alcohol by underage persons was deleted as covered by Code  6-1. It was derived from Code 2004,  38-396, and Ordinance No. 13-04,  1, December 27, 2004. 
Sec. 38-397. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- This section pertaining to transport or possession of alcohol in a motor vehicle was deleted as covered by Code  66-1. It was derived from Code 2004,  38-397 and Ordinance No. 13-04,  1, 12-27-2004. 
Secs. 38-398-38-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 8. - OFFENSES AGAINST GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS 

Sec. 38-431. - False alarms or reports. 
    No person shall knowingly and willfully furnish to any police officer, firefighter, police dispatcher, fire dispatcher or employee of the city, acting in the lawful discharge of his duties, a false name, address, age or date of birth, or a false or misleading report in connection with a fire, crime, police inquiry, medical emergency or traffic accident. 
(Code 2004,  38-431; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(2)) 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, MCL 750.240; false report of crime, MCL 750.411a. 
Sec. 38-432. - Resisting, opposing or hindering public officers or employees. 
    No person shall knowingly and willfully use any physical or verbal conduct which obstructs, resists, hinders or opposes any police officer, firefighter or any federal, county, state or city employee who is acting in the lawful discharge of his duties. 
(Code 2004,  38-432; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(1)) 
State Law reference- Obstructing police officer, MCL 750.479. 
Sec. 38-433. - Failure to obey public officers. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  When operating a motor vehicle which has been stopped in response to a police officer's signal, leave or attempt to leave the scene unless and until he has received permission to do so from the police officer. 
(2)  Knowingly and willfully fail to obey the command of any properly identified law enforcement officer to stop or halt. 
(3)  Knowingly and willfully fail to obey the command of any police officer who is directing traffic or engaging in crowd control or cross a police line without specific authority or the permission from a police officer at the scene in which the police line is constructed. 
(4)  Knowingly and willfully fail to obey the command of any law enforcement officer, school official, the mayor or other authorized representative of the department of public works and/or recreation departments to leave a public park, schoolground, playground, boulevard, swimming pool, recreation area, school building or city building when ordered to do so. 
(Code 2004,  38-433; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(6), (8)-(10)) 
State Law reference- Failure to obey police signal, MCL 750.479a. 
Sec. 38-434. - Aiding escape. 
    No person shall escape, attempt to escape or willfully engage in conduct which causes or allows the escape of any person while lawfully in the custody of any police officer. 
(Code 2004,  38-434; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(3)) 
State Law reference- Escapes, rescues and prison breaking, MCL 750.183 et seq. 
Sec. 38-435. - Failure to obey signs. 
    No person shall knowingly and willfully disobey any validly posted sign in any public park or other public place. 
(Code 2004,  38-435; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(5)) 
Sec. 38-436. - Defacing or tearing down official notices. 
    No person shall mutilate, deface, conceal or tear down any official notice or placard lawfully posted by any city officer or employee unless prior permission is given by such officer or employee to remove such notice or placard. 
(Code 2004,  38-436; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.305(9)) 
Sec. 38-437. - Concealing evidence of crime. 
    No person shall falsely indicate a lack of knowledge, or when asked by a law enforcement officer, a prosecuting attorney, the city attorney or a judge, fail to disclose or conceal knowledge of the actual commission of a violation of any statute or city ordinance from a prosecuting attorney, city attorney, judge or law enforcement officer investigating such violation. This section shall not be interpreted to conflict with the right of any person not to be a witness against himself or any other legally recognized privilege or right. 
(Code 2004,  38-437; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(7)) 
State Law reference- Perjury, MCL 750.422 et seq. 
Sec. 38-438. - Impersonation of public employee. 
    No person shall impersonate a firefighter, police officer or other employee of the city, or any government unit, without due authority. 
(Code 2004,  38-438; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.308(4)) 
State Law reference- False personation of officers, MCL 750.215. 
Sec. 38-439. - Vehicle radios receiving police frequencies; permit required. 
    No person who has been convicted of a felony during the preceding five years shall equip a vehicle or possess within a vehicle a radio receiving set that will receive signals sent on frequencies assigned by the Federal Communications Commission of the United States of America for police purposes, or use the same unless such vehicle is used or owned by a bona fide amateur radio operator holding a technician class, general, advanced, or extra class amateur license issued by the Federal Communications Commission. This section shall not be construed as restricting the use of radar detectors, or the ability of a person to transport within a vehicle an inoperable radio. 
(Code 2004,  38-439; Ord. No. 13-04,  1, 12-27-2004; Ord. No. 11-06,  1, 7-30-2006) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.508. 
Chapter 42 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to operate system of public recreation, MCL 123.51 et seq.; playground equipment safety act, MCL 408.681 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - PARK AND RECREATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 42-31. - Established. 
    There is established a park and recreation commission. 
(Code 2004,  42-31; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.151) 
Sec. 42-32. - Membership. 
    The park and recreation commission shall consist of nine persons who shall be residents of the city and who shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the city commission. One member shall be a city commissioner, one member shall be a board representative from the Kelloggsville School District and one member shall be a board representative from the city public schools. Members shall serve for three-year terms, with the first park and recreation commission being appointed so that three vacancies will occur each year. Members shall be appointed so as to take office in January following their appointment. The recreation director, public works director and city planner shall be ex officio members. 
(Code 2004,  42-32; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.151) 
Sec. 42-33. - Officers and meetings. 
(a)  As soon as may be convenient after the appointment of park and recreation commission members to succeed those whose terms have expired, members of the park and recreation commission shall meet and elect a chairman and vice-chairman. Names of the officers shall be submitted forthwith to the city clerk. The chairman shall preside at meetings of the park and recreation commission and in his absence such duties shall be assumed by the vice-chairman. The recreation director is responsible for keeping accurate minutes of the proceedings at each meeting. 
(b)  The park and recreation commission shall meet at regular intervals, but not less than four times each year. 
(Code 2004,  42-33; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.152, 35.153) 
Sec. 42-34. - Finances. 
    The appropriations made by the city commission in each year for park and recreation purposes shall be used for the operation, maintenance and improvement of city parks and to operate recreational programs in the city. 
(Code 2004,  42-34; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.154) 
Sec. 42-35. - Budget request. 
    Not later than March 1 in each year, the park and recreation commission shall file with the finance director a capital improvement budget request for the following year, itemizing, in detail, the purposes for which the funds requested will be used. Such requests shall be considered together with all other proposed budget items as required by the city Charter. 
(Code 2004,  42-35; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.155) 
Sec. 42-36. - Duties. 
    The park and recreation commission shall: 
(1)  Prepare and develop plans and programs for parks, playgrounds and recreation areas for the city. 
(2)  Appoint a representative to assist the mayor in interviewing and making recommendations for the appointment of a recreation director who is to report regularly to the park and recreation commission. 
(Code 2004,  42-36; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.157) 
Secs. 42-37-42-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 3. - PUBLIC USE OF PARKS 

Sec. 42-71. - Hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or be in any city park between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. without a written permit from the director of parks and recreation. The city activities center is exempt from such restriction at the discretion of the director of recreation; however, if the activities center is operating between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., the building/activity will be under continuous supervision by a member of the recreation department. Such a permit shall be issued upon a showing that there will be compliance with all other ordinances and a further showing that public peace and public safety will not be endangered. 
(Code 2004,  42-71; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.171) 
Sec. 42-72. - Operation of motorized vehicles. 
    No person shall operate any motorized vehicle, including snowmobiles, on any city park property, except in areas specifically designated for vehicular traffic. 
(Code 2004,  42-72; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.313(6)) 
Chapter 46 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Garbage disposal act, MCL 123.361 et seq.; solid waste facilities, MCL 324.4301 et seq.; hazardous waste management act, MCL 324.11101 et seq.; hazardous materials transportation act, MCL 29.417 et seq.; solid waste management act, MCL 324.11501 et seq.; waste reduction assistance act, MCL 324.14501 et seq.; clean Michigan fund act, MCL 324.19101 et seq.; low-level radioactive waste authority act, MCL 333.26201 et seq.; litter control, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Littering and junk. 
(a)  No person shall deposit, accumulate, throw, scatter, leave or place refuse, waste, debris, garbage, dead animals, leaves or other noxious or unsightly materials in or upon any public right-of-way or other public or private place or property. 
(b)  No person shall convey or transport junk, broken glass, scrap metal, metal shavings or other sharp or dangerous materials in any form over the public streets or alleys of the city unless such junk, glass, metal or other material shall be contained in a box or other receptacle, constructed so that such junk, glass, metal or other material cannot fall through the receptacle or over the sides of the receptacle onto the public streets or alleys of the city. 
(c)  Every person shall keep or permit within the lot line of his premises a suitable receptacle for depositing cans, ashes, glass or any metal, stone, earthenware or other such materials, and shall not litter his premises with such materials. 
(d)  The occupant of any premises or the person responsible for any premises within the city in which any refuse shall be accumulated which is not disposed of by an approved incinerator or garbage grinder, shall maintain on such premises one or more refuse containers with suitable tightly fitted covers, which shall be kept in a reasonably clean condition and shall be rodentproof. All residential garbage containers must be stored inside a structure or at rear or side of a building. No refuse container shall be filled beyond its capacity. Such container shall be placed out for proper collection of refuse no earlier than 6:00 p.m. on the day prior to the regularly scheduled collection day and removed as soon as practicable on such collection day. 
(e)  No person shall transport or dump any refuse or other waste materials in such a manner as to cause the littering or destruction of any stream, creek, ditch, drain, culvert or gutter. 
(f)  No occupant or owner of improved or unimproved property shall place, deposit, dump, scatter, leave or allow the accumulation of junk, scrap, debris, garbage, rubbish, industrial refuse, litter of any kind, waste materials, construction waste, waste products, excess dirt or soil, or any other dangerous or unsightly materials within the lot line of such property or upon the adjacent right-of-way. 
(g)  The city or its authorized representatives are hereby empowered to enter upon any premises in the city for the purpose of assessing cleanup costs, but only where notice of such action is first provided and the owner is afforded an opportunity to comply, and no person shall molest or interfere with the city or their authorized representatives, while they are engaged in such assessment as provided in this subsection. 
(h)  A person who violates any of the provisions of this section is responsible for a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 2004,  46-1; Comp. Ords. 1987,  35.058, 35.064) 
State Law reference- Littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 
Secs. 46-2-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved incinerator and approved garbage grinder mean incinerators and garbage grinders, respectively, which conform with all city ordinance requirements, are used exclusively to dispose of solid waste generated by the occupant of the site of generation on which they are located and are consistent with the plan. 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, refuse, wastewater sludge or other combustible materials. 
    Board of public works means the county board of public works established pursuant to the provisions of Public Act No. 185 of 1957 (MCL 123.731 et seq.). 
    Combustible waste means solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. Such term shall include garbage; combustible rubbish, such as paper; cardboard; cartons; wood; boxes; rags; cloth; bedding; leather; carpeting; combustible construction and demolition debris; and any other solid waste that is combustible in the MBI, as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. Such term shall exclude noncombustible solid waste, such as ashes; noncombustible rubbish; incinerator ash; incinerator residue; municipal and industrial sludges; animal waste; pathological and biological waste; asbestos and asbestos waste products; explosives; radioactive materials; appliances; concrete rubble; noncombustible construction and demolition debris; rock; gravel and earthen materials; automobiles; trailers; equipment wire and cable; all waste, other than solid waste, such as hazardous waste, site-separated materials and source-separated materials; and any other type of waste that is noncombustible in the MBI, as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. 
    Commercial/industrial license means a license to collect solid waste from any and all sources within the city, except single-family and duplex residential dwellings. 
    Commercial operation date means the date when the MBI has been completed and tested and is, in the sole opinion of the county, ready for full commercial operation. 
    County means the County of Kent, Michigan, acting by and through its board of commissioners or its department of public works. 
    Disposal site means any of the following: 
(1)  A solid waste transfer facility; 
(2)  A single incinerator having an average daily design capacity exceeding 50 tons of solid waste per day, or two or more incinerators located at one site, under the control of one person, and having an aggregate average daily design capacity exceeding 150 tons of solid waste per day; 
(3)  A sanitary landfill; 
(4)  A solid waste processing plant; or 
(5)  Any other solid waste handling or disposal facility utilized in the disposal of solid waste. 
    Garbage means rejected food wastes, including waste accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables. 
    Hazardous waste means hazardous waste as defined in part 111 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.11101 et seq.) and as identified in administrative rules promulgated pursuant to such act. 
    MBI means the mass-burn steam energy-generating incinerator, to be constructed by or on behalf of, or available by contract or lease with, the county within the City of Grand Rapids in accordance with the plan. 
    Plan means the county solid waste management plan approved by the county board of commissioners and the director of the department of natural resources, pursuant to the requirements and provisions of the state pursuant to part 115 of Public Act No. 451 of 1994 (MCL 324.11501 et seq.). 
    Premises means any enclosed area used for residential, commercial or industrial purposes, separately or in combination, to which a separate street address, postal address or box, tax roll description or other similar identification has been assigned to, or is in use by, a person having control of the area. 
    Residential license means a license to collect solid waste from single-family and duplex residential buildings in the city. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste, excluding ashes, consisting of combustible and noncombustible waste, including paper, cardboard, metal containers, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, demolished building materials or litter of any kind that may be a detriment to the public health and safety. 
    Site of generation means any premises in, or on, which solid waste is generated by any person. 
    Site-separated materials means recyclable materials, including, but not limited to, bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush and yard trimmings, that are separated from solid waste, after collection from a site of generation, by either a waste hauler or the operators of a disposal site to which it is delivered. 
    Solid waste means 
    garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, street cleanings, municipal and industrial sludges, solid commercial waste, solid industrial waste, and animal waste. However, the term "solid waste" does not include the following: 
(1)  Human body waste. 
(2)  Medical waste. 
(3)  Organic waste generated in the production of livestock and poultry. 
(4)  Liquid waste. 
(5)  Ferrous or nonferrous scrap directed to a scrap metal processor or to a reuser of ferrous or nonferrous products. 
(6)  Slag or slag products directed to a slag processor or to a reuser of slag or slag products. 
(7)  Sludges and ashes managed as recycled or nondetrimental materials appropriate for agricultural or silvicultural use pursuant to a plan approved by the state department of environmental quality. 
(8)  The following materials that are used as animal feed, or are applied on, or are composted and applied on, farmland or forestland for an agricultural or silvicultural purpose at an agronomic rate consistent with GAAMPS: 
a.  Food processing residuals and garbage. 
b.  Precipitated calcium carbonate from sugar beet processing. 
c.  Wood ashes resulting solely from a source that burns only wood that is untreated and inert. 
d.  Lime from kraft pulping processes generated prior to bleaching. 
e.  Aquatic plants. 
(9)  Materials approved for emergency disposal by the state department of environmental quality. 
(10)  Source separated materials. 
(11)  Site separated material. 
(12)  Coal ash, when used under any of the following circumstances: 
a.  As a component of concrete, grout, mortar, or casting molds, if the coal ash does not have more than six percent unburned carbon. 
b.  As a raw material in asphalt for road construction, if the coal ash does not have more than 12 percent unburned carbon and passes Michigan test method for water asphalt preferential test, MTM 101, as set forth in the state transportation department's manual for the Michigan test methods (MTM). 
c.  As aggregate, road material, or building material that in ultimate use is or will be stabilized or bonded by cement, limes, or asphalt, or itself act as a bonding agent. To be considered to act as a bonding agent, the coal ash must have at least 10 percent available lime. 
d.  As a road base or construction fill that is placed at least four feet above the seasonal groundwater table and covered with asphalt, concrete, or other material approved by the state department of environmental quality. 
(13)  Inert material. 
(14)  Soil that is washed or otherwise removed from sugar beets, has not more than 35 percent moisture content, and is registered as a soil conditioner under part 85 (MCL 324.8501 et seq.). Any testing required to become registered under part 85 is the responsibility of the generator.
