ARTICLE 4. - SKATEBOARD PIPES AND RAMPS 

Sec. 54-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Maximum height means the vertical height of the skateboard pipe or ramp, as measured from the supporting ground/surface to the uppermost construction of the skateboard pipe or ramp. 
    Minimum setback means the horizontal distance between any part of the skateboard pipe or ramp to any side or rear property line. 
    Skateboard pipe means all outdoor structures commonly known as pipes, with a shape of a half circle or oval, which are designed and principally intended to permit persons on skateboards to move continuously from one side to the other. 
    Skateboard ramp means all outdoor structures commonly known as ramps, with an upward inclined surface, essentially one of the two sides of a pipe, which are designed and principally intended to permit persons on skateboards to move from horizontal to vertical and back to horizontal. 
(Code 2004,  54-111; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.762) 
Sec. 54-112. - Finding of necessity. 
    The unregulated construction and use of skateboard pipes or ramps in the city can be detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of residents of the city, and that regulation of such ramps on the public ways and on residential properties is therefore essential. 
(Code 2004,  54-112; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.761) 
Sec. 54-113. - City commission approval required; application; fee; notice; hearing. 
(a)  No person shall construct or operate a skateboard pipe or ramp within the corporate limits of the city on property within a residential zoning district unless he shall first have obtained the approval of the city commission. 
(b)  Any person desiring to construct or operate a skateboard ramp within a residentially zoned district shall submit an application for such ramp to the building official, on forms approved by the building official, together with a fee as set by resolution of the city commission. The application shall set forth, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of the applicant and property owner, if different from the applicant. 
(2)  The location of the proposed skateboard ramp. 
(3)  A site plan showing the skateboard ramp's: 
a.  Dimensions; 
b.  Height; 
c.  Placement; 
d.  Distance from property lines; 
e.  Proximity to electric utility facilities; 
f.  Location and dimension of all other structures existing on the lot. 
(4)  The type of construction materials to be utilized. 
(5)  Any noise reduction measures to be utilized in such construction. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who will utilize the skateboard ramp. 
(7)  The hours of use or operation. 
(8)  The nature of any enclosures around the skateboard ramp. 
(9)  The name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of the responsible party, if other than the applicant. 
(10)  The signature of the applicant and property owner, if different from the applicant. 
(c)  Upon receiving an application which meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the building official shall notify, by regular U.S. mail, all property owners and residents within a radius of 300 feet of the property where the skateboard ramp will be located. Such notice shall set forth the date, time and location of the regular city commission meeting when the application will be submitted for city commission approval. The notice shall also state that the permit application is on file for public inspection and copying in the office of the building official. 
(d)  At the meeting referred to in subsection (c) of this section, the city commission shall review the application and shall approve the application, with or without conditions, or deny the application. If the application is approved, the building official shall issue a permit which incorporates any conditions of construction or operation adopted by the city commission. The city commission may consider the following, among other things: 
(1)  Skateboard ramp size and height; 
(2)  Proximity to adjoining properties and rights-of-way; 
(3)  Noise generation and noise mitigation measures; 
(4)  Proximity to electric utility facilities; 
(5)  Comments, if any, of other property owners and residents. 
(Code 2004,  54-113; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.765-20.767) 
Sec. 54-114. - Erection, placement or use on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, place or use a skateboard pipe or ramp on any public street, sidewalk, right-of-way, park or other public property or to skate onto any public property by means of momentum obtained by the use of any skateboard pipe or ramp. 
(Code 2004,  54-114; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.763) 
Sec. 54-115. - Residential property. 
(a)  General restrictions for skateboard pipes and ramps on residential property shall be as follows: 
(1)  The maximum height, minimum setback from all property lines and building permit requirements for skateboard pipes or ramps within residential zoning districts shall comply with the following table. Only one skateboard pipe or ramp shall be permitted on any residential property. 
Residential Zone Maximum Height Minimum Setback 
(Feet) Building Permit 
Requirement All residential zones Up to three feet 15 Building permit required Up to four feet 20 Building permit required Up to five feet 25 Building permit required Up to six feet 30 Building permit required  
(2)  Skateboard pipes and ramps shall not be located in any front yard or exterior side yard on a corner lot in any easement or in violation of any building line. 
(3)  The square foot area of land coverage by a skateboard pipe or ramp shall be counted as accessory use, lot coverage as required in each residential zoning district. 
(4)  The widest or longest dimension of the skateboard pipe or ramp shall face the dwelling unit and every petition of every such pipe or ramp shall be closer to the home of the property owner than to any property line. However, there shall be a minimum fire separation of at least ten feet between such pipe or ramp and the house. 
(5)  Skateboard pipes and ramps shall not be wider than two times the height of such pipe or ramp, measured by exterior outside dimensions. 
(6)  Skateboard pipes and ramps shall not be longer than three times the height of such pipe or ramp, measured by exterior outside dimensions. 
(b)  Additional requirements for skateboard pipes and ramps over three feet in height, as permitted in the table set forth in subsection (a) of this section, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Construction of all skateboard pipes and ramps shall comply with recognized engineering practices, including, but not limited to, materials, connectors, dead loads, live loads and impact loads. 
(2)  There shall be no storage of materials or equipment of any kind under the framework or structure of a skateboard pipe or ramp. 
(3)  No structural members of a skateboard pipe or ramp, on any side, shall be exposed, but shall be enclosed with the same type of materials as the rolling deck, and the enclosed walls shall include type R-13 sound-deadening insulation, at a minimum, to reduce the sound levels. 
(c)  Additional requirements for all skateboard pipes and ramps, regardless of the height or size thereof, shall be as follows: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to charge or receive any consideration for the use of a skateboard pipe or ramp, or to use or operate such pipe or ramp in a commercial manner in any residential district. 
(2)  Only one person may use the skateboard pipe or ramp at any one time. 
(3)  Except on Sundays, when skateboard pipes or ramps shall not be used until after 12:00 noon, use of such pipes or ramps shall be permitted only between the hours of 9.00 a.m. and sunset or 9:00 p.m., whichever occurs first. 
(Code 2004,  54-115; Comp. Ords. 1987,  20.764) 
Secs. 54-116-54-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 5. - PUBLIC EVENTS 

Sec. 54-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public events means parades, gatherings, exhibitions, displays or other special occasions held on public property, sponsored by persons or organizations other than the city. 
(Code 2004,  54-151; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.631) 
Sec. 54-152. - Permit required; fee. 
    Prior to the holding of any public event in the city, the sponsoring party must apply for and receive a permit for such public event from the office of the city clerk. No fee for such permit shall be required. 
(Code 2004,  54-152; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.632) 
Sec. 54-153. - Insurance. 
    Prior to the issuance of any permit for a public event, the applicant must present to the city clerk a certificate of insurance showing that the applicant and the city are insured for liability arising out of injury to persons and damage to property in amounts to be established by resolution of the city commission. Higher limits may be required by the city if such public event is of a hazardous nature, such as fireworks displays, tractor pulls and rock concerts. 
(Code 2004,  54-153; Comp. Ords. 1987,  21.633) 
Secs. 54-154-54-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 6. - CONTROL, MAINTENANCE AND REGULATION OF THE PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 

Sec. 54-170. - Designation of public works director as enforcement official. 
    The director of the department of public works and his designees are hereby authorized to enforce this article. 
(Code 2004,  54-170; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director means the director of the department of public works or his designee. 
    Driveway approach means that portion of a driveway within the public right-of-way which extends from the designed inner edge of the sidewalk to the back of curb, edge of street pavement or edge of a graded roadway. 
(Code 2004,  54-171; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-172. - Damage and obstruction prohibited. 
    No person shall make any excavation, cut or otherwise cause any damage to any street or public right-of-way in the city, except under the conditions of and in the manner authorized by this article. No person shall place any article, thing, or obstruction in any street or public right-of-way, except under the conditions of and in the manner authorized by this article, but these provisions shall not be deemed to prohibit such temporary obstructions as may be incidental to the expeditious movement of articles and things to and from abutting premises, nor to the lawful parking of vehicles within the part of the street or public right-of-way reserved for vehicular traffic. The city commission may authorize the city engineer, upon the recommendation of the city traffic engineer, to grant permits for certain uses in any street within the city which the commission deems to be for the benefit of the general public. Nothing herein shall be construed or interpreted as lessening the authority of the chief of police to issue and enforce traffic control and similar orders to the extent otherwise authorized by law. 
(Code 2004,  54-172; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-173. - Permits, fees and bonds. 
    Where permits are required in the article, they shall be obtained upon application to the city engineering department, upon such forms as they shall prescribe. Such application shall be accompanied by such fees as established by resolution of the city commission. Any permit issued under this article shall be valid only for the time stated thereon and may be revoked by the director for failure to comply with this Code, any rules and regulations adopted pursuant hereto, or any lawful order of the director. A condition for issuance of any permit under the provisions of this article is that the applicant will complete the work permitted, observe all pertinent laws and regulations of the city in connection therewith, repair all damage done to the street surface, or public right-of-way and installations on, over or within such street, or public right-of-way including trees, and protect and indemnify the city, its officers and employees against any claim for damage which may arise or be brought on account of injury to any person or damage to any property resulting from the work done under the permit or in connection therein. Where liability insurance policies are required to be filed in making an application for a permit, they shall provide coverage in amounts to be established by resolution of the city commission, except as otherwise specified in this article. A duplicate executed copy of the original of such certificate of insurance, naming the city, its officers and employees as additional insureds shall be filed with the engineering department. An original surety company bond in the amount of $20,000.00 conditioned upon performance of the conditions of the permit and compliance with all requirements of the law, in a form preapproved by the city, shall be filed with the city each year by contractors desiring to obtain permits through the year. 
(Code 2004,  54-173; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-174. - Specifications. 
(a)  All construction work in the public right-of-way requires a permit unless such work is: 
(1)  Directed by and on behalf of the city; or 
(2)  Unless the work involves the operation and maintenance of installations in the public right-of-way which work is performed pursuant to a written agreement between the city and another governmental body or its agent. 
(b)  Failure to obtain a permit before initiating any construction within the public right-of-way is a violation of this article. 
(c)  If any job or construction covered by this article is started before a permit is obtained, an amount equivalent to double the fee shall be paid prior to issuance of the permit. 
(d)  No building permit for construction or alteration of any building or structure shall be issued by the inspections department until the property owner has received the proper permits required under this article. 
(e)  When the construction involved is in connection with any sewer or water system, the permit shall be issued contingent on the contractor obtaining the necessary permit from the authorities in control of the system for making the proposed extensions and additions. 
(f)  All work shall be performed in such a way as to cause a minimum of inconvenience and restriction to both pedestrian and vehicular traffic, and shall be subject to the review and approval of the city traffic engineer. No dirt or other material shall be placed on sidewalks. 
(g)  All facilities, both below ground and above ground, shall be located as indicated by the city engineer. Pipes shall be placed to a depth that will provide not less than four feet of cover between top of roadway surface and the top of the pipe. If at any time the position of the facility interferes with improvements to the street or public right-of-way it shall be the responsibility of the applicant to move the facility to a location satisfactory to the city. All such moving shall be done at the sole expense of the applicant. 
(h)  The city engineer may suspend or revoke any permit issued pursuant to this article for failure to comply with the terms of the permit or this Code. The director may suspend or revoke such permit and order any work there under to cease by serving notice of such action and the reason therefore. 
(i)  In the event a permit issued under this article is revoked, a new permit must be obtained and a new fee paid. 
(j)  Issuance of a permit does not waive the necessity for other permits that may be required by other local, state or federal agencies. 
(k)  All work subject to permit issued in accordance with this article shall be done in conformance with City of Kentwood "Specifications and Conditions for Highway Permits" which is hereby adopted and as may be periodically amended by the city engineer. A current copy of the Specifications and Condition for Highway Permits shall be maintained in the office of the city engineer. 
(l)  The foreman in charge of any work being performed under this article shall have in his possession at all times a copy of the permit along with any specifications and conditions under which work is to be done. 
(Code 2004,  54-174; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005; Ord. No. 4-08,  1, 3-4-2008) 
Sec. 54-175. - Traffic protection. 
(a)  All openings, excavations and obstructions shall be properly and substantially barricaded and railed off, and at night shall be provided with prescribed warning lights. All traffic control devices shall conform to the Michigan Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. 
(b)  All openings and excavations shall, where necessary, be properly and substantially sheeted and braced as a safeguard to workers and to prevent cave-ins or washouts which would tend to injure the thoroughfare or subsurface structure of the street. 
(c)  At least five feet of sidewalk space shall be kept clean and clear for the passage of pedestrians. If construction operations are of such a nature and scope that such passage on the public sidewalk is impracticable, a temporary sidewalk with substantial railings or sidewalk shelter shall be installed around such obstruction as approved in writing by the city engineer. 
(d)  Permittees under this article shall designate a foreman who shall be responsible for overseeing the work and the principal contact person for the city. The permittee must give the foreman authority to carry out all the provisions contained in this article. If the permittee fails or refuses to carry out these provisions at the time, and in a manner which in the opinion of the director is necessary to protect and direct traffic, or if the permittee cannot be located and notified to do so, the city shall have the right to perform the work and the permittee shall reimburse the city for all charges incurred in the work within ten business days of being invoiced for the same. 
(e)  Excavated material shall be deposited so it will not interfere with moving traffic; and precautions must be taken to prevent excavated material from spilling out onto the traveled portion of the highway by temporary wooden retaining walls or other means approved by the director upon the recommendation of the city traffic engineer. 
(Code 2004,  54-175; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-176. - Street openings. 
    No person shall make any excavation or opening in or under any street or public right-of-way without first obtaining a written permit from the director. No permit shall be granted until the applicant shall post a cash deposit or bond and file a certificate of insurance and otherwise comply with this article. 
(Code 2004,  54-176; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-177. - Emergency openings. 
    The director may, if the public safety requires immediate action, grant permission to make a necessary street opening in an emergency, provided that a permit shall be obtained on the following business day and the provisions of this article are otherwise complied with. 
(Code 2004,  54-177; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-178. - Prohibited openings. 
    No permit to make any opening or excavation in or under a paved street shall be granted to any person within a period of five years after the completion of any paving thereof; provided, however, that the city engineer may suspend such prohibition where a street opening is required to protect the public health or safety, and subject to the payment of such fees established by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 2004,  54-178; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-179. - Additional regulation authorized. 
    The city engineer may make additional regulations pertaining to openings and excavations in the streets, curb cuts, or street obstructions, which regulations shall be subject to the approval of the city commission. No person shall fail to comply with any such regulations. 
(Code 2004,  54-179; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-180. - Removal of encroachment. 
    Whenever there is an encroachment, obstruction or excavation in the street or public right-of-way which has not been allowed under this article, the same shall be removed forthwith and any excavation refilled. The expense of such removal or refilling shall be charged to the person responsible for such unlawful encroachment, obstruction or excavation. 
(Code 2004,  54-180; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-181. - Notice of commencement of work. 
    Any person performing work under a permit granted pursuant to this article, or as approved by the city, shall notify the engineering department at least 48 hours before the work is to be started. No street opening shall be started on Saturdays, Sundays, holidays or the day before a holiday. All permittees must contact MISS-DIG 72 hours prior to excavation. 
(Code 2004,  54-181; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-182. - Temporary street closing. 
    Subject to the review and with the consent of the chief of police, the director shall have authority to temporarily close any street, or portion thereof, when he deems such street to be unsafe or temporarily unsuitable for use for any reason. He shall cause suitable barriers and signs to be erected on said street, indicating that the same is closed to public travel. When any portion of said street shall be closed for emergency repair work no person other than those responsible for making said repairs shall be permitted to drive a vehicle through said closure. No person shall move or interfere with any sign or barrier erected pursuant under this section without authority from the director. 
(Code 2004,  54-182; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-183. - Construction machinery. 
    All construction machinery shall be equipped with pneumatic tires when any work is done on blacktop or concrete surfaced pavements. 
(Code 2004,  54-183; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-184. - Curb cuts. 
    No opening in or through any curb or any street shall be made without first obtaining a written permit from the engineering department. Curb cuts and sidewalk driveway crossings to provide access to private property shall comply with the following: 
(1)  No single curb cut shall be less than ten feet in width, nor more than 30 feet in width, unless otherwise authorized by the engineering department. 
(2)  The minimum distance between any curb cut and a public crosswalk shall be ten feet. 
(3)  The minimum distance between curb cuts, except those serving residential property, shall be 25 feet; provided, however, that greater minimums may be required to implement city policies or as otherwise required to protect public safety. 
(4)  For any curb cut which terminates less than five feet from a construction joint, the contractor shall remove and replace the existing curb to the next joint. 
(5)  The necessary adjustments to utility poles, light standards, fire hydrants, catch basins, street or railway signs, signals, or other public improvements or installations shall be accomplished without cost to the city. 
(6)  All construction shall be in accordance with plans and specifications approved in writing by the city engineer. 
(7)  Curb cuts for private streets and private driveways shall include a minimum 24-inch wide concrete valley gutter and Michigan Department of Transportation "F-4" modified concrete curb and gutter, or other as approved by the city engineer, throughout the public right-of-way. The requirements of this subsection (7) are in addition to those set forth in chapter 18 of the zoning ordinance entitled "private street regulations." 
(8)  All curb cuts, except for single family residential driveways, shall also be required to have a concrete apron no less than six inches in thickness. 
(9)  Curb cuts along arterial roads shall comply with sections 17.10 and 17.11 of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 2004,  54-184; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005; Ord. No. 3-07,  1, 10-2-2007) 
Sec. 54-185. - Pavement openings. 
    Structures and appurtenances shall be placed under pavement by boring and jacking, or cutting through the pavement and using an open trench, and subject to the following: 
(1)  Tunneling will not be permitted. 
(2)  Cuts through concrete pavement shall be at right angles to the pavement centerline and shall be made at least six inches wider on each side than the width of the trench with a minimum width of 36 inches. 
(3)  Removal of all pavements shall be done only with concrete saw and chisels operated by hand or compressed air. 
(4)  Pavement crushers of any type are prohibited. 
(5)  Openings shall be trimmed in straight lines with right angle corners and vertical edges. 
(6)  When openings are five feet or less from an expansion or construction joints, the pavement shall be removed to the joint. 
(7)  When a pipe is installed by boring and jacking, the leading edge of the pipe must precede the auger by a distance equal to one-half the diameter of the pipe. The method to be used shall be approved by the city engineer before work is started. 
(8)  In case it is necessary to move any building or structure above or below the ground within the right-of-way of the highway, the right-of-way shall be restored to the satisfaction of the director. Underground structures damaged by boring shall be repaired or replaced at the cost of the permittee. 
(9)  Open trenches shall be not less than two feet wide, plus the diameter of the pipe, at the bottom of the excavation, and the maximum width shall be the diameter of the pipe, plus three feet, or as stated on the permit. 
(10)  The slope of the excavated trench shall not be less than one to one. 
(11)  Permanent wearing surface of bituminous material approved by the city engineer shall be placed in trenches on all blacktop surfaced roads. The thickness shall be equal to the depth of the original blacktop or three inches, whichever is greater. Permanent wearing surface of seven inches of road gravel approved by the city engineer shall be placed in trenches on all gravel or dirt roads. Permanent wearing surface on concrete surfaced roads shall be new concrete pavement of the same type, thickness and quality as the original pavement. All permanent wearing surfaces shall be placed by the applicant at his own expense. 
(12)  When tree roots are removed because of trenching, the top of the trees shall be trimmed sufficiently to balance the loss of roots. This trimming shall be done by the permittee under the direction of the city at the permittee's expense. When tree roots are bored for underground utility installations, the distance shall be one foot for each one inch of trunk diameter. 
(Code 2004,  54-185; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-186. - Backfilling. 
(a)  Within traveled right-of-way. Backfilling trenches within the traveled portion of the street (between the shoulders or curb line), shall comply with the following: Material may be sand, gravel, or sandy gravel and shall be placed in successive layers not more than six inches in depth, loose measure, and each layer shall be thoroughly compacted by mechanical compaction and all backfill subject to be checked by the controlled density method showing a minimum of 95 percent proctor. All material excavated from the trench, and not used in the backfill shall be hauled away. Any settlement shall be corrected within eight hours after notification to do so. 
(b)  Outside traveled right-of-way. Backfilled trenches outside the traveled portion of the street (between the shoulders or curb and right-of-way lines), shall comply with the following: Material may be sand, gravel, or the material removed from the trench, if not frozen, except across driveways where the materials shall be sand, gravel, or sandy gravel. All backfill shall be placed in successive layers not more than 12 inches in depth, loose measure, and each layer shall be thoroughly compacted by mechanical compaction and all backfill is subject to be checked by the controlled density method showing a minimum of 90 percent proctor. Topsoil and sod shall be replaced in all trenches across lawns. All material excavated from the trench, and not used in backfill, shall be hauled away. Any settlement shall be corrected within eight hours after notification to do so. 
(Code 2004,  54-186; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-187. - Utility poles. 
    Utility poles may be placed in streets in locations approved in advance by the engineering department As a condition to approval to install any utility or other pole in the public right-of-way, the city engineer shall retain the right to require the removal or relocation of the pole, at no cost to the city where necessary for a public improvement. 
(Code 2004,  54-187; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-188. - Maintenance of installations in street. 
    Every owner of, and every person in control of, any estate hereafter maintaining a sidewalk vault, coal hole, manhole, monitoring well, or any other excavation, or any post, pole, sign, awning, wire, pipe, conduit or other structure in, under, over or upon, any street which is adjacent to or a part of his estate, shall do so only on condition that such maintenance shall be considered as an agreement on his part with the city to keep the same and the covers thereof, and any gas and electric boxes and tubes thereon, in good repair and condition at all times during his ownership or control thereof, and to indemnify and save harmless the city, its officers and employees, against all damages or actions at law that may arise or be brought by reason of such excavation or structure being under, over, in or upon the street, or being unfastened, out of repair or defective during such ownership or control. 
(Code 2004,  54-188; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-189. - Sewer and water connections installed prior to paving or resurfacing. 
    Whenever the city commission shall determine to pave or resurface any street, all necessary sewer and water connections shall be installed in advance of such paving or resurfacing, and the cast shall be charged against the premises adjacent thereto or to be served thereby or as otherwise directed by the commission. Where such paving or resurfacing is financed, in whole or in part, by special assessment, the cost of such sewer and water connections may be a lien, collected and included as part of the special assessment for the cost of the sewer and water connections so installed, pursuant to chapter 50. 
(Code 2004,  54-189; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-190. - Clear vision corner. 
    Vision clearance shall be provided on all corner lots as adopted in Appendix A, section 3.06. 
(Code 2004,  54-190; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-191. - Moving of oversized and overweight objects. 
(a)  Oversized objects. Objects over ten feet in width or 65 feet in length or 13.5 feet in height are oversized for purpose of this section. Oversized objects to be moved on city streets, shall require the submission of an application to the engineering department for approval not less than 48 hours in advance of the move. All moving shall be done on pneumatic-tired trucks trailers, moving dollies or any combination thereof, and the load shall be distributed so that no axle will carry more than the legal load permitted by state or county regulations. Motive power shall be by pneumatic-tired truck or tractor and shall be of sufficient size to handle the load with slipping. No moving shall be permitted on Saturdays, Sundays, holidays or the day before a holiday unless authorized by the city. The contractor shall be responsible for furnishing all necessary means of traffic protection before any move is made in the road right-of-way. All such moves shall be coordinated with the city police department. 
(b)  Overweight objects. Overweight objects may be moved according to the legal limits permitted by the state or county regulations. The contractor shall submit an application to the engineering department for approval not less than 48 hours in advance of the move. All moving shall be done on pneumatic-tired trucks, trailers, moving dollies or any combination thereof. All provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall also apply to such moves. 
(Code 2004,  54-191; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-192. - Street trees. 
(a)  Purpose, interpretation and application. The provisions of this section shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements necessary and which are adopted for the promotion of the public health and safety and general welfare of the people of the city. The city retains the right to trim or remove any tree or shrubbery within a public right-of-way if, in the opinion of the director of public works or city traffic engineer, it is necessary to preserve public safety or protect public property. It is the intent of this section to promote and maintain a vibrant and healthy urban streetscape and canopy. Among other purposes, such provisions are intended to provide for the requiring of a permit to plant trees or shrubs or plants in any street right-of-way of the city; to prohibit the planting of certain kinds of trees, plants and shrubs in certain places; to authorize the removal and/or replacement of diseased trees, plants or shrubs, or in such cases where the existence of such trees, plants or shrubs can be proven to cause serious prolonged health conditions; and, to authorize the director of public works to promulgate rules and regulations relative to such planting, subject to the approval of the city commission. 
(b)  Scope. The provisions of this section shall govern the planting, trimming, removal or replacement of trees, plants and shrubs in any public right-of-way, particularly that space between the public sidewalk and the curb line. 
(c)  Supervision enforcement. The responsibility for the enforcement of this section shall be vested in the director of public works and duly authorized assistants or agents. 
(d)  Jurisdiction. The director of public works shall have jurisdiction over the planting, trimming or removal of any trees, plants or shrubs in the public streets of the city. 
(e)  Permit required. No person shall plant, place or remove any tree or shrub in any public right-of-way of the city without having first secured a permit as hereinafter provided. It is understood that should it be necessary to remove any permitted tree from within an existing right-of-way to facilitate right-of-way improvements they shall be removed without reimbursement to the adjoining property owner for loss of trees. 
(f)  Application for a permit to place, trim, plant or remove. Application for a permit to place, trim, plant or remove a shade or ornamental tree, plant or shrub with a mature height greater than 36 inches in any street of the city shall be made to the director of public works of the city. Such application shall be on forms provided by the director of public works. Application fees shall be as set forth from time to time by the city commission. 
(g)  Promulgation of rules. The director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate necessary rules and regulations to carry out the purpose of this section, and to protect the public health, safety, and welfare. The director of public works shall have the authority to recommend reasonable fees to be applied pursuant to this section. 
(h)  Approval. Rules and regulations provided for herein shall be submitted to the city commission for approval. No such rule or regulation shall become effective until approved by the city commission. 
(i)  Rules to be filed. Upon approval by the city commission, copies of the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder shall be kept on file at the office of the city clerk and the office of the director of public works for distribution to interested parties. 
(j)  Standards. The rules and regulations provided for herein shall establish the minimum distance between trees, shrubs and ornamental trees planted or placed in the streets of the city, which distance shall be such as will be beneficial to the growth of such tree, plant or shrub; shall prohibit the placing or planting therein of any trees, plants or shrubs that will endanger the public health or safety of the people of Kentwood; shall provide for the minimum open space around the trunk of any tree, plant or shrub placed therein, which distance shall be sufficient to encourage the growth of trees, plants and shrubs; shall set rules regarding and standards for removal and replacement of trees; shall set rules and standards for root trimming and cutting; shall prohibit the planting or placing of any tree, plant or shrub in any location that will create a dangerous or hazardous traffic condition, and the director of public works is hereby directed to confer with the chief of police, the city engineer, the community development director, and the city engineer, or any other official agency concerned in such cases. The director of public works is likewise empowered to vary the minimum distance between trees, plants and shrubs, in accordance with the variety of tree to be placed or planted within said streets of the city, and to make reasonable rules and regulations governing the placing of and maintenance of underground and aboveground public utility facilities in or near trees or tree roots. 
(k)  Modification. The director of public works is authorized to exercise discretion in the application of any rules or regulations promulgated hereunder, where practical difficulties in carrying out the strict letter of such rule or regulation would result in a personal hardship to someone affected thereby. Such applications, however, must be those of a character which will not impair the overall purposes and intent of this section. 
(l)  Trees not to be disturbed. No person shall remove, destroy, break, cut, deface, trim or in any way injure or interfere with any tree, plant or shrub that is or may be hereafter placed or planted in any street by the city, without a proper permit from the director of public works. Plants or shrubs planted in any right-of-way by adjoining property owners pursuant to a permit acquired herein may be trimmed or cut to properly maintain said plant or shrub without obtaining a permit hereunder. 
(m)  Not to apply to public improvements. The provisions of subsection (l) of this section shall not be construed to apply to the removal of any tree, root, plant or shrub, or any part thereof, wherever the removal of same shall be necessary for the construction of new sidewalk projects, roadways, streets, avenues, alleys, pavements, sewers, watermains, or other public improvements where such public improvement is authorized by any public governmental agency. 
(n)  Director of public works to be notified. Whenever any tree, plant or shrub must be removed, in whole or in part, because of the placing of a public improvement, the person responsible for the construction of said public improvement shall notify the director of public works of such necessity, not less than five working days, prior to the time work is to be done. 
(o)  Posters, etc., prohibited. No person shall attach or place any rope, wire, sign, poster, handbill or any similar object, on any tree now or hereafter planted or placed in any street. 
(p)  Deleterious substance. No person shall deposit or throw upon any street, parkway, avenue, alley, sidewalk, boulevard or gutter any material injurious to trees, plants or shrubs. This includes but is not limited to any poison, pesticide or chemical that is harmful to the tree or its root system. 
(q)  Trimming required. The owner of any tree or shrub on private property overhanging the right-of-way shall trim the branches to a height that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a space of ten feet above the surface of the right-of-way. The city shall have the right to trim any tree or shrub in the public right-of-way that has its root structure on private property when it interferes with: 
(1)  Pedestrian or vehicular traffic; 
(2)  With proper spread of light along the street from a street light; or 
(3)  Visibility of any traffic-control device or sign, such trimming is to be confined to the area within the right-of-way. 
The owner or owners of any premises adjacent to a street, avenue, alley, sidewalk or boulevard, or other public property shall trim all branches of any tree, plant or shrub on such premises which overhangs any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk or boulevard, gutter or other public property so that there shall be a clear height of a minimum of ten feet above the surface of the street and ten feet above a sidewalk or public property unobstructed by branches. 
(r)  Dead limbs and branches. The owner or owners of any premises adjacent to a street shall remove all decayed and broken limbs and branches from trees on such property where such limbs and branches overhang a street or public property. 
(s)  Power to examine. The director of public works shall have authority as may be necessary to enter onto any lot or premises within the city for the purpose of examining trees, plants and shrubs for infectious diseases which may constitute a hazard to the people of the city or to other trees, plants or shrubs in the city. 
(t)  Procedure, if infected. If the director of public works finds any tree, plant or shrub that is infected with a disease that constitutes a hazard to the people of the city, or to other trees, plants or shrubs in the city, the director of public works shall notify the owner of such tree, plant or shrub in writing and give to such owner 30 days in which to take such action as may be directed in the notice. If such owner fails to comply with the order of the director of public works, the director of public works shall have power to take such action as may be legally necessary to enter such lots or premises and remove said diseased tree, plant or shrub, and require the owner of such lot or premises to pay the cost of such removal. 
(u)  Decision final. The determination of the director of public works with regard to any decisions required under this article shall be the final administrative determination of the matter. 
(v)  Violation; enforcement. Violation of any provision of this section or of the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder, shall constitute a municipal civil infraction, with fines as set forth in section 54-195. The director of public works, or his designees, is authorized to issue municipal civil infraction citations or municipal civil infraction violation notices to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Code 2004,  54-192; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005; Ord. No. 3-10, 6-18-2010) 
Sec. 54-193. - Sidewalk and driveway approaches. 
(a)  Permits. No person, including the owner of the property abutting thereupon, shall construct, reconstruct or repair any public sidewalk, driveway approach, or curb in the city without first obtaining a permit therefore from the engineering department The engineering department is hereby authorized to issue such permit upon written application therefore and upon payment of the fee as established by resolution of the city commission. The city must also have on file an annual highway bond and certificate of insurance. 
(b)  Line and grade stakes. After a permit is issued, the engineering department shall, upon request from the contractor, furnish line and grade stakes as may be necessary for proper control of the work. The furnishing of line and grade stakes does not relieve the contractor of responsibility for making careful and accurate measurements in constructing the work to the lines furnished by the city engineer. Where it is necessary to replace engineer's stakes disturbed or destroyed without fault on the part of the city or its employees, a restaking charge shall be paid. 
(c)  Valve boxes and cleanouts. When valve boxes, sewer cleanouts, hand-hole covers, gas valves, hydrants or other utility installations occur in sidewalks or driveway approaches, proper allowances must be made for these structures. Metal castings or frames shall be adjusted to the finished grade of the sidewalk surface. Concrete shall be kept far enough away from the covers so that they can easily be removed and replaced after the concrete has set. When a box is not perpendicular to the slab surface, the major portion of the box cover shall be set below the surface. When larger openings exist leading to underground chambers, the covers for these shall be set about one-half inch higher than the average for drainage. In case of frames larger than six inches across standard sidewalk expansion joint material shall be placed on two adjacent sides of square or rectangular frames and completely around circular frames. This material may be one-quarter inch thick, but not over one-half inch thick. 
(d)  Single-family residential driveway approach. It shall be unlawful for anyone to construct a single-family residential driveway approach over, in or through any gutter or road ditch or to install or construct a single-family residential driveway culvert through any road, street or public right-of-way without first having obtained a permit from the engineering department. A driveway approach shall be six inches in thickness if concrete is used in lieu of asphalt and a maximum of 20 feet in width at the right-of-way line. Material and construction shall comply with the requirements of the state department of transportation current specifications for construction. 
(e)  Sidewalk specifications. Sidewalk installation shall be required as depicted in the attached Table "A". Sidewalk shall be five feet wide and shall be not less than four inches in thickness or less than six inches in thickness at driveway crossings. Material and construction shall comply with the requirements of the state department of transportation current specifications for construction. Six inch concrete forms shall be required for driveway approaches and public sidewalks adjacent to driveway approaches.

(f)  Obstructing drain. It shall be unlawful for anyone to obstruct the flow of stormwater in or through any driveway culvert, gutter or road ditch in or through any road, street or public right-of-way. 
(Code 2004,  54-193; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005; Ord. No. 8-06,  1, 4-30-2006; Ord. No. 3-07,  2, 10-2-2007) 
Sec. 54-194. - Block parties. 
(a)  Permit. Any person desiring to use any pubic street within the city for any block party or other social gathering shall first file an application with the city clerk. A permit shall only be issued by the clerk upon the recommendation of the director, police department and fire department. 
(b)  Application contents. The application shall identify the day and time the party is to be held. The location of the street closing also needs to be stated on the application. The applicant shall indemnify and hold harmless the city, if officers and employees from any and all claims arising out of the issuance of the permit or activities of the applicant. 
(c)  Streets where allowed. Only local streets with light vehicular traffic are permitted to be used as determined by the director. 
(d)  Barricades. Street barricades shall be obtained through the department of public works, upon payment of $25.00 deposit. The applicant will be responsible for the placement prior to and the removal of the barricades after the party. 
(e)  Damage and cleanup. The applicant shall be responsible for the cost of repairing or replacing any barricade damaged or destroyed. The applicant shall further be responsible for the clean up of the street and neighboring yards after the party. The deposit for the barricades may be returned to the applicant following inspection by city personnel. 
(Code 2004,  54-194; Ord. No. 7-05,  1, 5-1-2005) 
Sec. 54-195. - Violations; penalties, civil remedies. 
(a)  Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction and shall be fined not more than $2,500.00 for each violation. Any person, firm, or corporation who is found to be responsible for a subsequent violation of this article within a two-year period shall be fined double the amount assessed for the immediate preceding violation. 
(b)  A person, firm, or corporation found to be responsible for a violation shall pay costs and fees incurred by the city for correcting and abating the violation. If such costs and fees are not fully paid within 30 days of written notice thereof, the costs and fees may be assessed as a single lot assessment per chapter 10 of the city Charter and added to, and made part of, the tax roll for the subject property and may be collected in the same manner as provided by state law for the collection of taxes on real estate. The remedies of this subsection (b) are in addition to any other remedies at law of inequity. 
(c)  The city may also proceed against any person for a violation of this article by seeking injunctive relief and/or damages. 
(d)  Each day a violation exists or continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 2004,  54-195; Ord. No. 3-07,  3, 10-2-2007) 
Chapter 58 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General Property Tax Act, MCL 211.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Administration fee, penalty and interest-Summer taxes. 
(a)  A one-percent property tax administration fee shall be added to all summer property taxes. On all taxes paid after August 20, a three percent penalty charge shall be added to all summer property taxes. 
(b)  In addition, after September 1 and before settlement with the county treasurer, interest on the tax at the rate of one percent per month shall be added to the taxes collected by the treasurer. 
(c)  For purposes of determining the date payment of a tax is received under this section, only the date that the payment is physically received in the offices of the city treasurer shall be considered the date of receipt. 
(Code 2004,  58-1; Comp. Ords. 1987,  12.301, 12.302; Ord. No. 4-11,  1, 5-13-2011) 
State Law reference- Penalty charge authorized, MCL 211.44(7). 
Sec. 58-2. - Same-Winter taxes. 
(a)  A one percent property tax administration fee shall be added to all winter property taxes. On all taxes paid after February 14, a three percent penalty charge shall be added to all winter property taxes. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the penalty charge may be waived for the homestead property of a senior citizen, paraplegic, quadriplegic, hemiplegic, eligible serviceperson, eligible veteran, eligible widow or widower, totally and permanently disabled person, or blind person, as those persons are defined in chapter 9 of Public Act No. 281 of 1967 (MCL 206.501 et seq.), if: 
(1)  The person makes a claim before February 15 for a credit for that property provided by chapter 9 of Public Act No. 281 of 1967 (MCL 206.501 et seq.); 
(2)  The person presents a copy of the form filed for that credit to the treasurer; and 
(3)  The person has not received the credit before February 15. 
(b)  In addition, after the last day of February and before settlement with the county treasurer, interest on the tax at the rate of one percent per month shall be added to the taxes collected by the treasurer. 
(c)  For purposes of determining the date payment of a tax is received under this section, only the date that the payment is physically received in the offices of the city treasurer shall be considered the date of receipt. 
(Code 2004,  58-2; Ord. No. 4-11,  2, 5-13-2011) 
State Law reference- Penalty charge authorized, MCL 211.44(7). 
Secs. 58-3-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 2. - TAX EXEMPTIONS FOR CERTAIN HOUSING PROJECTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Housing project tax exemption and service charges, MCL 125.1415a. 

Sec. 58-31. - Eligible property. 
    The tax exemption established in section 15a(1) of Public Act No. 346 of 1966 (MCL 125.1415a(1)) (hereinafter referred to as the "Act") shall not apply to any housing project within the city, except government assisted housing projects providing below market rental housing exclusively for low and moderate income elderly families, handicapped persons or families where: 
(1)  Financing has occurred under Section 8 of the U.S. Housing Act of 1937, as amended by the Housing Community Development Act of 1974, as amended (referred to in this article as "Section 8"); 
(2)  Financing has occurred through the state housing development authority's (referred to in this article as the "authority") issuance of tax free bonds; 
(3)  The housing project has been allocated low income housing tax credits by the authority; or 
(4)  The rental housing for low and moderate income families is receiving a mortgage loan from the authority and low income housing tax credits under section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code necessary in order to implement a substantial rehabilitation project for the property. 
(Code 2004,  58-31; Comp. Ords. 1987,  18.051; Ord. No. 16-03,  18.051, 11-10-2003) 
Sec. 58-32. - Time for commencement. 
    The tax exemption described in section 58-31(1) shall be available commencing with the 1980 assessment roll; the tax exemption described in section 58-31(2) shall be available commencing with the 1985 assessment roll; the tax exemption described in section 58-31(3) shall be available commencing with the 1994 assessment roll; and the tax exemption described in section 58-31(4) shall be available commencing with the 2004 assessment roll. 
(Code 2004,  58-32; Comp. Ords. 1987,  18.052; Ord. No. 16-03,  18.052, 11-10-2003) 
Sec. 58-33. - Duration. 
(a)  Effective dates. 
(1)  The exemption granted pursuant to section 58-31(1) shall remain in effect for 50 years or for as long as any portion of the financing pursuant to Section 8 remains outstanding and unpaid, whichever is less. 
(2)  The exemption granted pursuant to section 58-31(2) shall remain in effect for 50 years or for as long as any portion of the financing received through the authority's issuance of tax free bonds remains outstanding and unpaid, whichever is less. 
(3)  The exemption granted pursuant to section 58-31(3) shall remain in effect for 50 years or for as long as the authority allocates low income housing tax credits, whichever is less. 
(4)  The exemption granted pursuant to section 58-31(4) shall remain in effect for the lesser of: 
a.  50 years; 
b.  So long as the authority mortgage loan remains outstanding and unpaid; or 
c.  So long as the authority has an interest in the property. 
(b)  Continuation. The exemptions granted pursuant to section 58-31 shall continue only during such time as the housing project has complied with the act as of the date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 2004,  58-33; Comp. Ords. 1987,  18.055; Ord. No. 16-03,  18.055, 11-10-2003) 
Sec. 58-34. - Service charge. 
(a)  Certain qualified rental units. 
(1)  The service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for that part of a tax exempt housing project financed in accordance with Section 8 shall be equal to an amount determined by the following formula: 
The contract rents for the preceding calendar year for the housing project, less any charges for gas, electricity, heat or other utilities furnished to the occupants, less the service charge paid for the previous calendar year, times six percent. For purposes of this formula, the term "contract rents" shall be interpreted in accordance with the rules adopted pursuant to the United States Housing Act of 1937 as amended by the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, as amended. 
(2)  The service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for that part of a tax exempt housing project financed in accordance with the authority's issuance of tax free bonds or allocation of low income housing tax credits shall be equal to an amount determined by the following formula: 
The actual rents collected for the preceding calendar year, less any charges for gas, electricity, heat or other utilities furnished to the occupants, times six percent. 
(3)  The service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for a tax exempt housing project being substantially rehabilitated and financed with a mortgage loan from the authority and receiving low income housing tax credits shall be equal to an amount determined by the following formula: 
The actual rents collected for the preceding calendar year less any charges for gas, electricity, heat or other utilities furnished to the occupants, times six percent. 
(b)  All other property of the housing development. The service charge to be paid each year in lieu of taxes for that part of a housing project which is tax exempt pursuant to this article and the act, and which is occupied by other than low income elderly families, handicapped persons or families of low or moderate income shall be equal to the full amount of the taxes which would be paid on that portion of the project if the project were not tax exempt. If this subsection is applicable to a housing project, then the benefits of any exemption granted by this article and the act shall be allocated by the owner of the housing project exclusively to low income elderly families, handicapped persons or families in the form of reduced housing charges. 
(c)  Reservation of right to change. The city commission retains the right to change the service charge applicable to any class of housing project, except for those where the city has by resolution entered into, or shall enter into, a contract not to change the service charge. 
(d)  First year for new construction and rehabilitation projects. The service charge for the first year of tax exemption for housing developments consisting of new construction or rehabilitation projects which do not benefit from tax exemption and a payment in lieu of taxes at the time a new resolution is being requested under this article shall be equal to the greater of the: 
(1)  Service charge which would be applied pursuant to subsections (a) and (b) of this section; or 
(2)  Ad valorem property tax which would have been assessed to the property as of the normal tax date for the first exemption year, based on a valuation of the property as it existed prior to commencement of the construction or rehabilitation. 
For projects benefiting from tax exemption and payments in lieu of taxation at the time a request is made under this article for a new or continued exemption, the payment in lieu of taxation for the calendar year in which a new exemption is established shall be determined as set forth in the resolution applicable to that project. 
(e)  Payment. The service charge in lieu of taxes as determined in this section shall be payable in the same manner as general property taxes are payable to the city, except that the annual payment shall be paid on or before May 1 of each year, commencing with the year for which the exemption is granted. 
(Code 2004,  58-34; Comp. Ords. 1987,  18.053, 18.054; Ord. No. 16-03,  18.053, 18.054, 11-10-2003; Ord. No. 02-10,  1, 4-9-2010) 
Sec. 58-35. - Reports. 
    Any housing project obtaining tax exemption pursuant to this article and the act shall provide to the city such information as the city determines is reasonably necessary to verify the amount of the service charge for each year and the project's compliance with the other terms of this article and the act. 
(Code 2004,  58-35; Comp. Ords. 1987,  18.056)
